Project  1  is  classified  as  category  B–sensitive    according  to  the 
Environment Policy (2002) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  for  Project  1  was 
undertaken  on  the  basis  of  the  IEEs  of  four  subprojects,  along 
the  sector.  An 
with 
environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  (EARF)  was 
also  prepared 
the  environmental  assessment  of 
subprojects in future loans, including those that may be classified 
as  category  A.  The  Summary  IEE  of  Project  1  and  the  EARF  of 
the program have been disclosed in accordance with ADB’s “120 
days” rule . 
 
The  proposed  Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector  Development 
Investment Program (the Program) will foster economic growth in 
the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K). It involves the expansion 
of  basic  services,  such  as  water  supply,  sanitation,  waste 
management,  urban  transport,  and  other  municipal  functions,  in 
Jammu,  Srinagar,  and  other  important  towns  and  commercial 
centers. The investment program  will also strengthen the service 
delivery  capacity  of  the  responsible  state  urban  agencies  and 
urban local bodies (ULBs) through management reforms, capacity 
building, and training.  
 
The  multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF,  or  the  Facility)  will 
finance  projects  under  the  investment  program,  provided  the 
Government of India and the government of J&K comply with the 
assurances  to  ADB  and  the  constituent  projects  are  in  line  with 
those  assurances  and  with  the  criteria  set  out  in  the  Framework 
Financing Agreement (FFA). 
 
ADB  will  provide  loans  to  finance  projects  under  the  Facility  as 
soon  as  the  projects  are  ready  for  financing  upon  submission  of 
satisfactory  related  periodic  financing  request.  Each  loan  will 
constitute  a  tranche  and  may  carry  terms  different  from  the 
financing terms of previous or later loans. The choice of financing 
terms  will  depend  on  the  project  and  ADB’s  financing  policies  at 
the  time  the  loan  is  documented  in  a  legal  document.  Tranches 
may be provided in sequence or simultaneously, and may overlap.

Apart  from  the  national  priority  of  planned  development  of  major 
urban centers in India, the proposed investment program will also 
foster economic revival in J&K, where trade, services, and tourism 
are the principal drivers of the economy. Low investment in asset 
creation  and  in  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  and  lack  of 
structured institutional systems constrain growth in J&K. The state 
government  intends  to  promote  economic  growth  through  better 
service,  public  health,  and  environmental  conditions  by  investing 
in urban infrastructure and improving the management capabilities 
of its line agencies and the participating cities and towns. 
 
The  core  strategy  is  to  provide  investment  funds  in  a  prioritized 
manner,  building  on  the  infrastructure  rehabilitation  being  carried 
out  under  the  ongoing  loan  (2151-IND:  Multisector  Project  for 
Infrastructure  Rehabilitation  in  J&K),  with  planned  expansion  in 
tandem  with  urban  governance  improvements  and  reforms.  The 
state needs to balance progress on reforms, priority infrastructure 
investments,  and  private  sector  investment  particularly  in  trade 
and  tourism.  A  sector  loan  with  an  MFF  offers  the  borrower  the 
investment  decisions  on  priorities  and 
flexibility  of  basing 
constraints  defined  in  the  sector  policy  and  master  plans.  The 
subsector  master  plans  being  developed  as  part  of  the  ongoing 
loan will form the basis for investments made under the Facility. 
 
Subsector  master  plans  and  growth  trends  indicate  a  need  for 
about  $2  billion  equivalent 
to  2026) 
in 
infrastructure  investments  in  the  principal  centers.  The  state 
proposes to obtain about $1.29 billion of this amount for the most 
urgent  requirements  from  various  funding  sources  including  the 
proposed  Program  and  the  ongoing  Jawaharlal  Nehru  National 
Urban  Renewal  Mission  (JNNURM),  the  urban  reform  and 
investment program supported by the Government.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector 
Development Investment Program (the Program).1  
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis of the Urban Sector in Jammu and Kashmir 

2. 
The  state  of  Jammu  and  Kashmir’s  (J&K)  economy  depends  mainly  on  agriculture, 
tourism,  services  and  handicrafts. The  basic  urban  services  in  the  main  towns  are  dilapidated 
and grossly undersized due in part to in-migration from the rural areas and partly due to a lack 
of investment. However, economic activity is improving and the service sector which has grown 
over the last 5 years now contributes more than 50% of the state’s gross domestic product. The 
planned  and  sustainable  growth  of  the  urban  centers,  particularly  the  two  principal  cities  of 
Srinagar and Jammu, where the bulk of trade and commerce takes place, is an essential part of 
J&K’s economic strategy, as stated in its 11th Five Year Plan (2007–2012). 
 
J&K, spread over an area of 222,236 square kilometers (km2), comprises three distinct 
3. 
regions—Jammu,  Kashmir,  and  Ladakh—divided  into  14  districts,  with  a  population  of 
10.14 million (2001 census). The population is mostly rural, the urban population being less than 
25% (24.81%). The urban population of 2.52 million (2001 census) is distributed over 75 census 
towns, but about 63% live in Jammu and Srinagar. Jammu and Srinagar are important trading 
centers for the surrounding predominantly rural areas. Some district centers are growing tourist 
destinations, which also require support with planning, developmental controls and financing of 
basic infrastructure to encourage and support private sector investments. 
 
4. 
In  Jammu  and  Srinagar  only  40%  of  the  population  has  access  to  safe  drinking  water 
and  more  than  32%  of  the  urban  population lives  in  slums where  basic  amenities are  lacking. 
The  new  settlements  in  Srinagar  and  Jammu,  swelled  with  600,000  migrants  from  the  rural 
areas,  lack  piped  water,  proper  sanitation,  and  proper  road  access.  Improving  literacy  is 
increasing  the  aspirations  of  the  younger  urban  population  for  better  economic  opportunities, 
public  health,  cleaner  environment  and  better  quality  of  life.  Public  demand  for  improvements 
has increased since the first municipal elections in Jammu and Srinagar were held in 2005.   
 
 
 
5. 
Tens of thousands of pilgrims visit religious shrines in the area for various festivals and 
along with the increasing tourists, both domestic and foreign, require better facilities to protect 
the  fragile  environment.  Srinagar  in  particular  has  a  large  tourist  population  in  the  summer 
months,  drawn  by  the  world-famous  Dal  Lake  and  the  tourist  areas  in  Kashmir,  including  the 
regional towns and pristine mountain areas, to which the city is the gateway.  
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

The 2001 populations in Srinagar and Jammu2 were 971,357 and 607,642, respectively. 
6. 
The  outdated  and  undersized  urban  facilities  suffer  weak  operation  and  management.  More 
than 96% of the households in both cities have access to piped water, but with more than 50% 
system losses due to leaks, illegal connections, and poor records. Ad hoc and partial extension 
of the distribution network to provide basic services to the migrant areas has led to low levels of 
                                                 
1 The design and monitoring framework for the investment program is in Appendix 1.  
2  Only the municipal area and not the surrounding urban agglomeration. 

 

 2 

 

supply,  particularly  in  Jammu,  where  some  areas  receive  only  1–2  hours  of  water  per  day. 
Water supply operations in both cities suffer acutely from frequent and extended electric supply 
shortages, low voltage, and low pressure at higher points and ends of the distribution systems. 
To  address  the  most  urgent  needs,  ADB  provided  Loan  2151-IND3 (the  ongoing  project)  to 
rehabilitate  the  water  supply  systems  including  pumping  machinery,  treatment  plants,  and  the 
transmission  and  distribution  network.  Water  supply  in  the  key  towns  and  commercial  centers 
requires  expansion,  and  new  sewerage  systems  and  improved  solid  waste  management  are 
needed to protect public health and the environment. 
 
7. 
Srinagar  and  Jammu  lack  piped  systems  for  sewage  collection  and  requires  more 
treatment  capacity.  While  many  houses  in  the  less  densely  populated  areas  of  Jammu  have 
septic tanks, most houses in the more congested parts of Jammu and Srinagar discharge their 
wastes  into  open  surface  drains  endangering  public  health  and  water  quality  in  local  streams, 
rivers, and lakes. In the older sections of both cities night soil is commonly collected manually 
and  improperly  disposed  into  local  drains  and  solid  waste  containers.  The  regional  towns  and 
commercial centers have no sewage collection and disposal facilities. Most dwellings rely on pit 
latrines and commercial developments use septic tanks. 
 
8. 
In Srinagar, the fragile ecosystem of lakes and water bodies is seriously endangered by 
the  discharge  of  untreated  municipal  sewage  and  dumping  of  solid  wastes.  Lakes  and  other 
water  bodies  are  becoming  increasingly  polluted  by  sewage  from  surrounding  residential  and 
commercial developments, and the hundreds of houseboats on the lakes which are popular with 
tourists, causing eutrophic conditions with heavy weed and algal growth. Unless the pollution is 
intercepted,  the  water  quality  will  continue  to  deteriorate  damaging  the  environment  and 
discouraging tourism. Under a program sponsored by the Government, sewage collection and 
treatment facilities are being built to intercept and treat sewage from the areas around Dal Lake. 
But  additional  funding  is  needed  to  connect  properties  to  the  street  lines  and  to  extend  the 
sewage  networks.  The  ongoing  project  is  rehabilitating  sewerage  and  drainage  pumping 
stations  and  updating  integrated  sewerage  and  drainage  master  plans  to  guide  the  additional 
investments in cities and towns participating in the Program. 
 
9. 
Less than half of the municipal solid waste (MSW) in Srinagar and Jammu is collected. 
MSW in Srinagar goes to a designated dump site, but this operation is unscientific and receives 
biomedical  wastes  and  night  soil.  The  site  threatens  the  quality  of  groundwater,  emits  odors, 
attracts  flies  and  other  vectors  and  requires  upgrading  or  closure.  Jammu  has  no  designated 
disposal  area  and  solid  waste  is  indiscriminately  dumped  in  drains  and  along  riverbanks, 
causing  grave  risk  to  water  quality,  the  environment  and  health  of  downstream  users.  In  the 
smaller district towns and tourist areas, collection is not organized and indiscriminate dumping is 
threatening not only the health of local citizens but also the environment. 
 
Traffic  congestion  caused  by  security  operations,  lack  of  regulation,  and  the  growing 
10. 
numbers  of  personal  vehicles  is  not  only  costing  productive  time  and  wasted  fuel  but  also 
causing  air  pollution  in  both  cities.  While  the  ongoing  project  is  rehabilitating  roads  and  some 
bridges, it will not build new facilities. City growth strategies and updated master plans are being 
developed to guide investments under the Program. 
 
11. 
The  earthquake  on  8  October  2005,  which  devastated  large  areas  in  neighboring 
Pakistan  and  caused  extensive  damage  in  northwest  areas  of  J&K,  underscored  the  need  for 

                                                 
3  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan to India 
for the Multisector Project for Infrastructure Rehabilitation in Jammu and Kashmir. Manila (Loan 2151-IND, for $250 
million, approved on 22 December 2004).  

 

  

3

 

 

disaster  mitigation  measures.  As  most  of  the  state  is  in  earthquake  zone  5  (severe  risk)  new 
and existing building will need to be strengthened against earthquakes. 
 
12. 
Urban Planning and Governance. J&K has special status within the Indian Union and 
is  not  required  to  follow  the  provisions  of  the  74th  Constitutional  Amendment  Act,  which 
empowers  local  city  governments.  But  the  state  introduced  the  revised  Municipal  Act  in  2000 
and  held  elections  in  Jammu  and  Srinagar  in  2005.  However,  effective  urban  management  is 
constrained by the multiplicity of institutions with overlapping responsibilities and lack of funds. 
The functions of the municipal corporations of Jammu and Srinagar are confined to public health 
services such as SWM, food quality, vital statistics, vector control, building regulation and other 
basic  development  management  functions.  Water  supply  and  sewerage,  and  drainage  are 
respectively  provided  by  the  Public  Health  Engineering  Department  (PHED)  and  the  Urban 
Environmental  Engineering  Department  (UEED)  of  the  state.  Local  authorities  are  responsible 
for town planning and land development but do not have the capacity to make or enforce plans. 
As a result ad hoc and unplanned building activity, sale of public lands, and unregulated urban 
expansion have resulted. 
 
13. 
Institutional  Finances.  All  cities  and  towns  rely  on  the  state  for  about  80%  of  their 
budget. Their local revenues are limited to rentals from commercial establishments and building 
permit  fees,  which  have  not  kept  up  with  the  market.  Property  tax  as  provided  for  under  the 
Municipal  Act  is  not  implemented  by  the  cities.  Less  than  50%  of  water  consumers  are 
registered  and  billed,  and  PHED  only  charges  50%  of  the  cost  of  providing  the  water  supply 
services. Moreover, it collects from only about half of those billed, so the revenues only account 
for  about  11%  of  the  actual  costs.  Power  supply,  the  most  significant  cost  of  water  supply, 
particularly in Jammu, are directly paid by the state and are not recovered from users by PHED.     
 
14. 
Revenue  generation  and  budgeting  by  the  cities  is  hampered  by  the  lack  of  their  own 
revenue  sources,  irregular  fund  transfers  from  the  state  to  PHED  and  UEED,  and  outdated 
accounting  practices.  The  bulk  of  financial  resources  are  spent  on  salaries  and  administration 
expenses, leaving limited resources for operation and maintenance (O&M). J&K is committed to 
making services more efficient and service providers more accountable to citizens. The state is 
a  signatory  to  the  Urban  Reforms  Initiative  Fund  Program  of  the  Government,  under  which 
states must show their commitment to accounting and cost recovery reforms to gain access to 
grants under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM). JNNURM is a 
central  government  initiative  to  assist  63  major  cities  of  India  with  their  urban  infrastructure 
projects on the basis of comprehensive development plans and commitment to a range of urban 
sector  reforms.  The  conditions  for  JNNURM  grant  funds  are  basically  the  same  as  those  of 
ADB.  As  part  of  its  urban  road  map,  the  state  is  incorporating  JNNURM  funds  for  the 
development of Srinagar and Jammu.   
 
External  Assistance.  The ongoing project is the first major external assistance to J&K 
15. 
in  the  past  20  years.  Appendix  2  gives  details  of  external  support  to  the  urban  sector  in  India 
and shows that since 1993, ADB has provided 31 technical assistance (TA) grants and 12 loans 
amounting  to  $17  million  and  $2.9  billion,  respectively.  The  assistance  has  been  aimed  at 
poverty  reduction  through  shared  growth,  social  development,  and  good  governance.  These 
objectives  have  been  translated  into  action  through  integrated  urban  infrastructure  projects. 
ADB provided a project preparation technical assistance (PPTA) 4515-IND4 for the Program. 
 
16.   Ongoing  Project. The ongoing project has been under implementation for the past 24 
months.  Contracts  worth  $80  million  in  ADB  financing  have  already  been  awarded  and  $10 
                                                 
4   ADB.  2004.  Technical  Assistance  to  India  for  Preparing  the  Proposed  JKUSDP.  Manila  (PPTA  4515-IND  for 

$500,000, approved on 22 December 2004).  

 

 4 

 

million have been disbursed. At the current rate of progress, the detailed design and tendering 
of  all  civil  works  packages  under  the  project  will  be  completed  by  September  2007.  The 
progress is generally satisfactory, especially given the special circumstances in J&K. 
 
Lessons. ADB’s experience in the urban sector in India as summarized in the recently 
18. 
completed  urban  sector  study5 shows  that  urban  sector  projects  are  inherently  complex  and 
their  implementation  requires  close  coordination  between  several  agencies,  experienced  staff 
and  strong  support  from  senior  levels  of  the  state  government.  Institutional  reforms  such  as 
increases  in  water  supply  and  sewerage  tariffs  are  needed  but  are  not  acceptable  unless 
preceded  by  infrastructure  expansion,  improvement  of  services  and  extensive  stakeholder 
consultation.  Even  modest  increases  in  property  tax,  tariff  structures  and  reforms  in  municipal 
management  are  difficult.  Land  acquisition,  resettlement  and  statutory  clearances  from  central 
and  state  agencies  such  as  the  National  Highways  Authority  of  India,  state  pollution  control 
boards, railways and forest departments need to be taken into account at the design stage.  
 
19. 
Implementation of urban projects is slow mainly due to a lack of experience with major 
investment  programs.  Experienced  dynamic  high-level  project  leadership  by  the  executing 
agency (EA) and adequately trained and experienced staff are prerequisites. These are lacking 
with  state  agencies  and  cities,  especially  when  it  is  their  first  externally  aided  project. 
Compliance with the safeguards and guidelines of the state, India and ADB requires provision of 
support and training. The lack of experienced consultants and contractors in the urban sector is 
a  major  cause  of  delays,  exacerbated  by  the  booming  economy.  These  human  resource 
constraints are slowing planning, design, procurement and construction activities on all projects 
including the ongoing one in J&K. Contracts, particularly for sewerage works often have to be 
extended  to  more  than  twice  the  contracted  period.  The  ongoing  project  in  J&K  indicates  that 
capable contractors are more likely to bid for larger rather than smaller packages. 
  
20. 
Another  reason  for  slow  implementation  in  the  past  has  been  lack  of  project 
preparedness  by  the  EAs  resulting  in  more  than  2  years  of  time  lost  while  the  EA  was  being 
staffed and consultants were recruited. Lack of data and information during project preparation 
impedes project planning, substantially delays design and implementation, leads to changes in 
scope and time overruns. The average time to complete urban projects in India is 8 years.  
 
21. 
These  lessons  were  incorporated  in  the  formulation  of  the  proposed  Program.  The 
components of the project were selected after extensive consultation with various stakeholders 
taking  their  priorities  and  demands  into  account  in  the  design.  The  institutional  development 
component  is  designed  to  ensure  the  availability  of  adequate  financial  resources  for  O&M 
through  well-defined,  regular,  and  targeted  fund  transfers  from  the  state  to  the  responsible 
institutions in the near to mid term, enhancement of staff capacities through structured training 
and  skill  upgrading  programs,  and  gradual  transformation  of  user  departments  toward  more 
business-oriented operations. Further, the priority investments are linked to incremental reforms 
with substantive support for reforms and capacity building as part of the first tranche. Capacity-
building  activities  in  the  road  map  include  support  for  the  transition  to  modern  accounting 
systems in the municipal corporations, business process improvements through e-governance, 
legislative  changes  and  other  institutional  development  activities,  hands-on  training  in  project 
implementation, and support for knowledge management. 
 
22. 
Program Rationale. The rationale for the Program includes the Government’s priority to 
improve  planning  and  development  of  major  urban  centers,  and  the  economic  revival  of  J&K. 
The  state  intends  to  promote  economic  growth  by  improving  service  levels,  public  health  and 

                                                 
5 ADB. 2006. Special Evaluation Study on Urban Sector Strategy and Operations. Manila (June).  

 

  

5

 

 

environmental  conditions,  and  management  capabilities  in  state  line  departments  and  in  the 
participating  cities.  The  core  strategy  is  to  provide  investment  funds  in  a  prioritized  manner, 
building  on  the  rehabilitation  of  essential  infrastructure  under  the  ongoing  loan  with  planned 
expansion  in  tandem  with  improvements  and  reforms  in  urban  governance  in  the  participating 
cities.  The  Government’s  JNNURM  proposals  have  been  incorporated  in  the  design  of  the 
Program  and  the  sector  loan  format  provides  the  flexibility  to  balance  physical  expansion  with 
urban  reforms  and  capacity  development  over  the  8  year  Program  period.  The  master  plans 
being updated under the current loan will form the basis for later investments in the Program.  
 
23. 
The  master  plans  and  projected  urban  growth  patterns  have  been  used  to  develop  a 
road map for about $2 billion of investments in urban related infrastructure through 2026 in the 
Jammu, Srinagar and key towns and commercial centers in J&K. The state proposes to obtain 
funding for the most urgent works required over the next 10 years estimated to cost $1.26 billion 
as  follows;  $110  million  from  the  ongoing  ADB-financed  project,  about  $200  million  from 
ongoing planned expenditures, $500 million from JNNURM and $454 million under the Program. 
The  remaining  $740  million  required  in  the  latter  part  of  the  20-year  period  would  be  raised 
through  a  combination  of  state  and  Government  support,  commercial  borrowings,  and  public-
private partnership arrangements, which should evolve as the two cities improve their financial 
situation over the next 10–15 years. 
 
The road map for the Program includes extensive support for institutional development. 
24.  
The  principal  reforms  include:  (i) cost-reflective  and  volume  based  tariffs  for  water  supply  and 
sewerage services, (ii) property tax, (iii) transfer of responsibility for water supply and sewerage 
services  in  Srinagar  and  Jammu  to  semiautonomous  water  and  sewerage  boards,  (iv)  locally 
driven  urban  planning  and  control,  and  (vi)  development  of  public-private  partnerships  in 
provision  of  services.  Legislation  already  is  in  place  for  volume  based  charges  for  water  and 
sewage,  and  for  property  tax.  Further  legislation  to  strengthen  the  fledgling  municipal 
corporations may be required to transfer the responsibility for provision water and sewage to the 
cities  from  the  current  state  departments.  Capacity  building  includes  transition  to  modern 
accounting  systems 
the  municipal  corporations,  computerization,  business  process 
improvements  through  e-governance,  hands-on  training  in  project  planning,  design  and 
implementation, and support for knowledge management activities.

III. 

THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Impact and Outcome 

25. 
The  proposed  Program  will  improve  urban  services  to  Indian  standards  in  the  main 
urban  areas  of  J&K,  promote  commerce,  improve  service  access  by  the  poor  and  generally 
support the reviving economy of the state. It will improve public health, the urban environment 
and  living  conditions  for  the  2 million  people  projected  to  live  in  the  two  principal  cities  of 
Srinagar and Jammu and the participating towns, as well as for the growing numbers of tourists.  
 
B. 

Outputs 

26. 
The outputs of the investment program are grouped into two parts. Part A will improve 
(i) water  supply  systems,  by  rehabilitating  and  expanding  distribution  networks  and  setting  up 
new supply systems; (ii) sewerage and sanitation, by extending existing systems, constructing 
new  ones,  and  supplying  sanitation  maintenance  equipment;  (iii)  MSW  collection,  processing, 
treatment,  and  disposal  through  sanitary  landfills;  (iv)  road  and  intersection  capacity,  road 
safety, and  pedestrian overpasses; and (v) other municipal facilities that may be prioritized as 
the master plans are updated and finalized in the participating towns and cities. Part B covers 

 

 6 

 

management  and  implementation  support  required  to  implement  the  physical  works  and  a 
comprehensive capacity-building and institutional development program that will result in a more 
responsive state system, empowered local governments, a separate entity for managing water 
supply and sewerage services on modern business principles, improved financial performance 
of the local bodies and service providers, and overall improved levels of service to citizens.  
 

1. 

Part A: Urban Infrastructure and Services Improvement 

 
27.  Water  Supply.  With  the  rehabilitation  of  the  water  supply  systems  in  Srinagar  and 
Jammu under the ongoing project, adequate water supply production, treatment, transmission, 
and distribution capacity is expected to be available by 2009 to meet the water supply needs of 
the  projected  population  in  both  cities  until  2020  and  capacity  expansion  will  be  limited. 
However, there will be a strong focus on better management of water supply operations through 
a demand management and metering plan. Works will be selected according to the master plan 
priorities and the outcome of the leakage detection and hydraulic modeling studies done under 
the ongoing project. Combined with the ongoing project, the Program will provide water of good 
quality and adequate pressure, commensurate with Indian standards of 135 liters per capita per 
day,  in  all  areas  of  the  two  principal  cities  by  2012.  The  Program  will  also  rehabilitate  and 
expand  water  supply  systems  in  Pahalgam,  Gulmarg,  Sonamarg,  Patnitop,  and  other  towns 
selected for their economic importance to the state. 
 
28. 
Sewerage and Drainage. Consistent with government policy, sewerage investments will 
focus  on  high  density  areas  where  piped  underground  sewerage  is  the  best  alternative  for 
improving sanitation and public health. Separate collection systems will be installed in the more 
recently  developed  areas  of  the  cities  and  district  towns  where  road  carriageways  are  wide 
enough.  But  in  the  old  city  core  areas  where  streets  are  narrow  a  combined  system  for 
collecting sewage and storm water, with treatment of the dry weather flow will be provided. In 
congested areas where there may be no room to install conventional systems, community/public 
sanitation facilities connected to the water and sewerage networks will be set up. The Program 
will provide sewage collection and treatment for 75% and 30% respectively of the urban areas 
of Srinagar and Jammu, with the remainder being provided by JNNURM as required. Drainage 
rehabilitation  works  in  the  ongoing  project  are  addressing  the  most  urgent  problems  and  the 
master plans being prepared will identify further works under the Program.  
 
Solid Waste Management (SWM).6 The SWM works aim to increase service coverage 
29. 
to 100% in both cities and participating district towns. The feasibility of linking the Program with 
the Carbon Market Initiative7 and the Clean Development Mechanism8 will be explored as part 
of  detailed  planning.  The  state  will  ensure  that  biomedical  waste  from  private  hospitals  and 
clinics  is  disposed  of  as  legislated.  But  facilities  for  collecting  and  properly  disposing  of 
biomedical wastes from public hospitals will be incorporated in the Program.

and applicable policies and procedures of ADB, India and the state; in which case loan funds may be available for 
the subproject in the new site subject to compliances with all requirements under the Loan Agreement.. Additionally 
if the site is to be relocated the loan funds may also be used to finance proper closure of the existing site.

30. 
Urban  Transportation.  The  Program  will  improve  or  provide  (i)  connectivity  through 
expansion of transportation facilities to major activity centers and towns (ii) facilities for off-street 
parking;  (iii)  pedestrian  safety  through  subways  and  overpasses;  (iv)  street  lighting;  and  (v) 
bridges and grade-separator flyovers or underpasses to decongest traffic, reduce pollution, and 
improve the efficiency of public transport systems.  
 
31. 
Other Municipal and Urban Infrastructure. This component could include preservation 
of heritage, park and lake improvement, and other public facilities that may be identified in the 
master  plans  and  economic  opportunity  development  plans  (EODPs)  for  the  economically 
important  towns.  Selected  public  buildings  in  Srinagar  and  Jammu  such  as  schools  and 
hospitals may also be retrofitted to reduce earthquake damage. 
 
32. 
Under the first project of the Facility (Project 1) 4 subprojects, representative of the type 
of infrastructure investments envisioned under the Program, have been identified and prepared 
for the water supply, sewerage, SWM and urban transportation subsectors. These subprojects 
include the environmentally sensitive SWM component in Srinagar and the Bannihal Cart road 
expansion  in  Jammu,  for  which  a  full  resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared  (Supplementary 
Appendix  G).  The  process  of  identifying  and  appraising  the  technical,  economical,  financial, 
social,  and  environmental  aspects  of  these  subprojects  will  be  adopted  for  all  subsequent 
subprojects. Detailed design and tender documents of these 4 subprojects have been finalized.  
 

2. 

Part  B:  Capacity  Building,  Institutional  Development,  Governance,  and 
Investment Program Management 

 
33. 
The  capacity-building  program  will  support  the  state’s  urban  institutional  and  financial 
reform  agenda  with  particular  emphasis  on  developing  the  fledgling  municipal  corporations  of 
Srinagar  and  Jammu  into  viable  entities  by  2015.  The  institutional  development  will  develop 
municipal  management  capability  including  planning,  budgeting,  accounting,  computerization, 
revenue enhancement and e-governance. The key actions to be supported are as follows:   

(i)

Strengthening  the  urban  development  and  environmental  policy  framework  for 
land  use  and  zoning,  slum  improvements  and  provision  of  basic  services, 
including human resource requirement. The outputs will clarify institutional roles 
and  responsibilities,  need  for  legislative  amendments  or  bylaws,  administrative 
orders,  and  a  framework  for  state-level  capacity  building,  including  support  for 
training in municipal management and the formulation of options for reorganizing 
the water supply and sewerage operations in the state;

 Capacity-Building  Assistance  for  More  Efficient  Service  Delivery.  For  water  and 
34. 
sewerage  this  will  include  assistance  in  creating,  in  each  of  the  two  main  cities,  a 
semiautonomous  entity  or  board  equipped  with  modern  operating  and  financial  management

Support will also be provided in exploring and developing options for introducing private sector

35.  Management  of  the  Investment  Program.  This  component  will  provide  funds  for 
implementing  the  Program,  development  and  updating  of  various  master  plans,  incremental 
administration  costs,  consulting  services  for  design  and  construction  supervision,  project 
management and quality control, information dissemination, and the planning, appraisal, survey, 
and detailed design of the subprojects for the next tranche. The acquisition of office equipment, 
including  vehicles,  computers,  and  special  design  tools  and  software  for  design  and 
construction management, is included.   
 
C. 

Special Features 

36. 
Urban  Sector  Governance  and  Reforms.  The  brand-new  status  of  the  municipal 
corporations  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar,  the  first  elections  were  held  in  2005,  provides  an 
opportunity  to  develop  the  new  municipal  corporations  properly  from  the  ground  up,  thereby 
avoiding  some  of  the  poor  practices  inherent  in  long-established  corporations.  The  Program 
combines physical infrastructure improvements with gradual reforms and capacity building. An 
8-10 year time frame is expected to be required before the municipal corporations can become 
autonomous.  This  long  term  approach  lends  itself  to  the  sector  loan  modality  and  the 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) as requested by the state and the Borrower. 
 
37.  MFF  (or  the  Facility):  The  Program  will  be  an  essential component  of  the  larger  road 
map  for  the  urban  sector.  Under  the  Facility,  up  to  $300  million  in  loan  funds  will  be  made 
available to J&K in tranches on a demand basis. Succeeding loans under the MFF will only be 
made when proposed improvements have been properly appraised, designed and are ready for 
implementation.  The  Facility  provides  flexibility  in  the  choice  of  the  eventual  components, 
enabling the state to mix and match funds from various sources with the demand, considering 
the capacity of the responsible agencies to carry out O&M of the new facilities. Also, since the 
state  is  new  to  major  projects,  the  8-year  MFF  approach  gives  the  state  time  to  develop  the 
capacity of the responsible institutions as well as to plan and prepare succeeding subprojects. 
Moreover,  the  Facility  will  allow  the  design  and  implementation  of  different  tranches  and  the 
ongoing loan to be appropriately staged so that overlapping of activities is minimized. The EA 
can thus make the best possible use of its limited staff resources. The Facility also provides the 
flexibility of developing the towns as demand opportunity arises.  
 
D. 

Program Investment Plan

will be submitted by the Government in the agreed format. The Government will inform ADB of a 
forthcoming PFR at least 15 days before its submission. A PFR may cover several subprojects 
and  related  consulting  service  packages.  ADB  will  review  the  PFRs  and,  if  it  finds  them 
satisfactory, prepare the related loan and project agreements. The Government has submitted 
to ADB the first PFR for an amount of $42.2 million. Succeeding PFRs will be for at least $40 
million.

G. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Program Management 

The Economic Reconstruction Agency (ERA) will be the EA of the Program. The ERA, 
43. 
as mandated by the government of J&K, is responsible for all externally aided projects. Policy 
direction  and  strategic  oversight  will  be  provided  by  a  governing  body  under  the  minister  for 
planning.  The  chief  secretary  of  the  government  of  J&K,  the  principal  secretary  for  state 
planning  and  development,  the  commissioner/secretary  of  finance  of  the  state,  three  sitting 
members  of  the  state  legislative  assembly,  and  the  chief  executive  officer  (CEO)  of  the  ERA  
are the other members of the governing body. An executive committee established by the State 
shall be responsible to guide ERA on matters related to project activities. With the CEO of the 
ERA  as  chair,  the  executive  committee  comprise  of  the  following  officials  as  members:  the 
principal secretary for tourism, the public works commissioner/secretary, the housing and urban 
development commissioner/secretary, the secretary to government for public health engineering 
and  irrigation,  the  secretary  to  government  for  planning  and  development.  The  executive 
committee will make decisions according to the authority delegated by the governing body and 
will  provide  day-to-day  administrative  guidance  to  the  CEO  of  the  ERA.  Local  level  steering 
committees will be created in each city with representatives of the various line departments to 
facilitate interaction between the ERA and the participating agencies, to select subprojects and 
review  their  scope  and  design,  to  monitor  implementation  and  institutional  reforms  to 
disseminate information, and to coordinate approvals and clearances among agencies. 
 
44. 
PMUs in each of Jammu and Srinagar have already been established under the ERA for 
the  implementation  of  the  ongoing  project  and  the  Program  will  follow  the  same  procedures. 
Each PMU is headed by a full-time project director, reporting to the CEO. The project directors 
will  be  supported  by  PMU  staff  comprising  water  supply,  sewerage,  solid  waste management, 
urban  transportation,  financial  and  economic  analyst,  procurement,  social  development, 
environmental,  and  procurement  specialists  and  project  advisory  consultants.  A  senior  officer 
reporting  directly  to  the  CEO  will  be  responsible  for  institutional  development  and  capacity-
building activities. Another senior officer also reporting directly to the CEO will be appointed to 
ensure  compliance  with  environmental  and  social  safeguard  policies.  Each  PMU  will  have  a 
dedicated  financial  and  accounts  officer  to  look  after  the  project  accounts  and  processing  of 
claims.  The  PMUs  will  be  responsible  for  identifying,  formulating,  appraising,  designing,  and 
implementing  all  subprojects, 
including  compliance  with  state  and  national  statutory 
environmental regulations and ADB’s social and environmental safeguard policies. Community 
consultation will be an integral part of the operating procedure of the project. A total complement 
of 60 professional staff is estimated to be required in the two PMUs for the implementation of 
Project 1. The implementation and  tranche schedules are in Appendix 4, while the organization 
chart is in Appendix 5.

4. 

Implementation Period 

 
48. 
The  MFF  will  be  implemented  over  8  years  as  shown  in  Appendix  4  as  an  essential 
component of the larger road map for the sector, through 4 tranches.11 The 4 subprojects in the 
first loan were selected because they are ready for implementation and are representative of the 
components  of  the  Program.  The  institutional  and  capacity-building  activities  in  the  ongoing 
project,  including  the  ADB  funded  specialist  consultants  will  continue.  The  subprojects  in  the 
second  and  third  tranches  will  be  based  on  the  updated  master  plans  for  water  supply, 
sewerage, drainage, and SWM improvements and as land is acquired for new subprojects. The 
fourth  and  other  subsequent  tranches  (if  required)  will  focus  on  other  municipal  infrastructure, 
including  components  that  will  facilitate  investment  in  important  service  sectors  and  industries 
based  on  the  economic  development  plans  and  capacity  are  developed  in  the  regional  towns 
and commercial centers. 
 

5. 

Procurement 

 
Procurement  financed  from  the  ADB  loans  under  the  Facility  will  be  carried  out 
49. 
according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2006, as amended from time to time). International 
competitive bidding (ICB) will be followed for civil works contracts costing $10 million or more. 
Civil works contracts costing less than $10 million will be procured through national competitive 
bidding  (NCB).12 Single-stage,  two-envelope  bidding  with  post-qualification  will  be  adopted  for 
all ICB and NCB civil works contracts under the investment program. Works related to low-cost 
sanitation,  public  toilets,  and  restoration  of  structures  with  historical  and  tourism  importance, 
and  estimated  to  cost  less  than  $100,000,  will  be  evaluated  individually  for  the  feasibility  of 
direct contracting. Force-account procedures will be followed for specialized facilities (electricity 
connections, railway and national highway crossings) by state and Government agencies.  
 
50.  Water supply, sewerage, and drainage contracts may involve civil works combined with 
the supply and installation of equipment or goods and will be considered as civil works contracts 
regardless of the proportion of costs associated with the equipment or goods. ADB’s standard 
documents  for  procurement  of  plant  will  be  used  for  such  contracts.  In  procuring  goods  and 
related services, ICB procedures will be used if the estimated cost is at least $1 million and NCB 
procedures  if  the  cost  is  less  than  $1  million.  For  contracts  involving  specialized  equipment, 
such as proprietary software and small materials, valued at less than $100,000, ADB’s shopping 
procedures may be followed. 
 
NCB  for  civil  works  will  use  the  standard  documents  for  local  (national)  competitive 
51. 
bidding  (civil  works)  and  supply  contracts  will  use  the  documents  for  international  shopping 
(goods) already used in the ongoing project, as amended and approved by ERA and ADB. For 
small community works not exceeding $100,000 in value the option of community participation 
in  procurement  will  be  considered  as  per  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  The  contract 
packaging  in  the  procurement  plan  was  prepared  on  the  basis  of  experience  gained  in  the 
ongoing  project,  which  resulted  in  good  competition.  An  indicative  procurement  plan  for  the 
Program and a detailed procurement plan for Project 1 are in Appendix 6.

institutional development, and capacity building. In addition, independent agencies, institutions

7. 

Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing 

ADB  Management  has  approved  advance  contracting  for  consultant  recruitment  and 
54. 
procurement of goods and civil works, and retroactive financing for the Project 1 under the MFF. 
For  subsequent  loans, ADB  may  agree  to  the  request  for  advance  contracting  and  retroactive 
financing  of  civil  works  and  equipment  and  materials,  and  recruitment  of  consulting  services, 
subject  to  these  being  requested  under  the  following  PFRs  and  subject  to  being  eligible  in 
accordance  with  the  agreed  procedures  and  guidelines  on  a  project  by  project  basis.  These 
arrangements will facilitate the readiness of projects under the Program and will be considered 
for  subsequent  projects  during  the  processing  of  individual  PFRs.  Total  eligible  expenditure 
under retroactive financing will not exceed an amount equivalent to 20% of the individual loan, 
and must have been incurred not more than 12 months before the signing of the related legal 
agreements.  However,  approval  of  advance  action  and  retroactive  financing  does  not  commit 
ADB to finance the projects being developed under the Program. 
 

8. 

Governance and Anticorruption Efforts 

55. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended from time to time) was explained to and 
discussed  with  the  ERA.  ADB  has  assessed  the  financial  management  policies  of  the  ERA 
(Supplementary  Appendix  B)  and  agreed  on  measures  to  improve  governance,  accountability, 
and transparency with ERA. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, 
and  transparency,  ADB  reserves  the  right  to  investigate,  directly  or  through  its  agents,  any 
alleged corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Program. To support 
these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  will  be  included  in  all  bidding 
documents.  In  particular,  all  contracts  financed  by  ADB  in  connection  with  the  Program  shall 
specify  the  right  of  ADB  to  audit  and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  EA  and  all 
contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Program.  
 
56. 
In  parallel  with  the  physical  investment,  the  investment  program  is  also  designed  to 
support a number of initiatives to strengthen urban governance in the project cities. These will 
include (i) land use planning and formulation of an environmental policy framework; (ii) human 
resource  development;  (iii)  capacity  enhancement  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar  municipal 
corporations; and (iv) creation of a separate semiautonomous, self-sufficient, and commercially 
run  entity  for  water  and  wastewater  services  in  each  of  the  two  main  cities,  equipped  with 
modern operation and financial management tools and skills.

9. 

Disbursement Arrangements 

Loan  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  according  to  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook 
58. 
(2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To  facilitate  the  implementation  of  the  Program,  the 
Borrower  will  establish  an  imprest  account  for  each  loan  with  the  Reserve  Bank  of  India.  The 
ERA may establish a second-generation imprest account (SGIA) for each loan with in a current 
account in a commercial bank acceptable to both ADB and the Borrower. The imprest accounts 
will be established, managed, replenished, and liquidated according to the handbook. The funds 
from  the  imprest  account  will  be  transferred  to  the  SGIA.  The  Government  has  assured  ADB 
that all transfers from the imprest account to the SGIA will be made within 30 calendar days of 
the receipt of the advance or replenishment.  
 
59. 
The initial and all subsequent amounts to be deposited into the imprest account and into 
the  SGIA  will  be  determined  by  ADB  in  consultation  with  the  Government  and  the  ERA,  with 
particular  reference  to  the  pipeline  of  awarded  contracts.  The  drawdown  will  not  exceed  the 
equivalent of 3 months of projected expenditures or 10% of the total loan amount, whichever is 
less,  and  will  be  based on  disbursements  expected  under  contracts  within  the  next  3  months. 
The ERA will maintain each SGIA advance or replenishment in the separate commercial bank 
account established for the SGIA, and draw from it only the portion of expenditures eligible for 
ADB financing. Counterpart funds will be required for each such expenditure. ADB will provide 
guidance  in  the  establishment  of  accounts  for  the  Program  during  the  loan  inception  mission. 
The statement of expenditures (SOE) procedure will be used in reimbursing and liquidating the 
SGIA  for  eligible  expenditures  not  exceeding  $50,000  per  payment,  except  as  ADB  may 
otherwise agree during the implementation of the Program. 
 

10. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting 

60. 
The  ERA,  through  the  PMUs,  will  establish  and  maintain  separate  records  for  works, 
goods,  and  services  financed  out  of  loan  proceeds.  Also  through  the  PMUs,  the  ERA  will 
maintain separate project accounts according to generally accepted accounting principles for all 
expenditures  incurred  under  the  Facility  and  the  subprojects,  whether  out  of  loan  proceeds  or 
from  other  sources.    The  ERA  will  record  in  a  transparent manner  all  funds  received  from  the 
State, ADB, and other sources. 
  
Detailed  consolidated  annual  project  accounts,  as  maintained  by  the  ERA  through  the 
61. 
PMU,  will  be  audited  by  independent  auditors  whose  qualifications,  experience,  and  terms  of 
reference are acceptable to ADB, and will be submitted to ADB within 9 months of the end of 
the fiscal year. The annual audit report will include the audit of the imprest account, the SGIA, 
and the SOE procedure, and will specifically include a separate audit opinion on the use of loan 
proceeds, the operation of the SGIA, and compliance with SOE procedures and loan covenants. 
The ERA has been made aware of ADB’s policy regarding the delayed submission of audits and 
the requirements for a satisfactory and acceptable audit of accounts.

performance for each month by the PMUs and the local steering committees will be completed

reviewed.  ADB  will  review  the  quarterly  progress  reports  during  the  review  missions  to  be 
carried  out  at  least  twice  a  year,  and  during  the  tripartite  reviews  chaired  by  the  Government. 
ADB  will  also  carry  out  annual  environmental  reviews  of  the  Program.  In  addition,  a  midterm 
review of the investment program will be conducted in June 2012. The review will cover contract 
awards  and  disbursement,  implementation  progress  including  progress  against  institutional 
development  and  capacity-building  milestones,  social  and  environmental  aspects,  and  the

IV. 

INVESTMENT PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

1. 

Economic and Financial Analysis 

 
The  cost-benefit  analysis  of  the  4  subprojects  in  Project  1 confirmed  they  are  a  logical 
66. 
subset of the portion of the sector road map to be financed through the MFF. In addition to the 
physical  investments,  the  policy  and  organizational  changes,  capacity-building  and  other 
institutional changes, were analyzed to develop a plan for adequate revenues to meet the O&M 
costs in the mid term and operating cost in the longer term. These policies are as important as 
the  physical  investments.14 Thus  the economic  analysis  confirmed;  (i) rationale  for  government 
involvement,  (ii) goals  of  the  plan,  (iii)  sector  development  plan,  (iv) associated  economic 
policies,  (v) government  capacity,  (vi)  fiscal  impacts,  (vii) economic  risks,  (viii)  government 
commitment, (ix) coordination of foreign aid, and (x) conditions attached to the loan. Details of 
this analysis are in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 
67. 
The  economic  rationale  for  the  Government’s  intervention  is  sound,  as  the  Program 
supports  local  government  functions.  These  primarily  deal  with  basic  public  services 
characterized  by  monopolistic  conditions,  management  of  externalities,  and  protection  of  the 
public good. Subprojects are selected with the help of cost-benefit analysis/least-cost approach 
while  still  meeting  technical  and  safeguard  requirements.  A  comparison  between  the  baseline 
scenario and the alternative scenario over the period from 2007–2008 to 2015–2016 shows that 
the total fiscal burden in terms of the higher fiscal deficit that is attributed to ADB’s project varies 
between  0.1%  in  2007–2008  and  0.6%  in  2011–2012  (Supplementary  Appendix  B).  Despite 
assistance from the center, the state’s fiscal position remains weak. 
 
68.  With  limited  tax  instruments,  an  inadequate  tax  base,  and  unutilized  non-tax  sources 
municipal  corporations  are  highly  dependent  on  fiscal  transfers  from  the  state.  Funds  are 
primarily transferred through the devolution of the net tax revenue of the state and grants. The 
devolution  of  the  state’s  net  tax  revenue  to  local  bodies  is  a  constitutional  requirement  (74th 
constitutional  amendment),  and  its  magnitude  depends  on  the  recommendation  of  the  State 
Finance Commission. As recommended by the first State Finance Commission, the government 
of J&K shares 10% of net tax revenue with local governments through block grants for general 
or  specified  purposes.  Given  the  fragile  financial  status  of  municipal  corporations,  revenue-
generating subprojects can only achieve financial viability over the medium term. Water charges 
are low and often uncollected and a property tax system does not exist, so resistance to sharp 
hikes in user charges and introduction of property taxes is expected, and the delivery of public 
utilities and services will continue to depend on government subsidies. 
 
69. 
The financial analysis of sample subprojects incorporates this reality, and that J&K will 
receive  ADB’s  loan  funds  as  90%  grant.  However,  the  existing  system  needs  to  be  reformed 
and the revenue-generating subprojects need to be financially viable against a benchmark cost 
of  capital.  There  is  no comparative  rate-tenor  combination  to  ADB;  the closest  market  rate  for 
medium-term funds (10–15 years) is around 9%. The current rate of inflation is in the region of 
5%,  implying  a  benchmark  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  of  4%  for  each  subproject.  
Alternative  non-volume-based  user  charges  and  taxes  have  been  worked  out  for  the  sample 
subprojects on this assumption (Supplementary Appendix A). For example, at least a sevenfold 
                                                 
14 David  Dole.  2005.  Assessing  Aid  for  a  Sector  Development  Plan:  Economic  Analysis  of  a  Sector  Loan.  ERD 

Technical Note, No. 14. Manila: ADB.   

 

  

19

 

 

increase  in  the  current  domestic  water  supply  charges  will  be  needed  to  achieve  the  target 
FIRR. However, setting user charges or taxes at such high levels is not feasible at this juncture. 
The  strategy  is  to  improve  the  recovery  of  O&M  cost  gradually  by  improving  the  coverage  of 
households, changing illegal users to bill-paying customers, gradual increase of user charges, 
billing and collecting from all consumers, reducing physical and administrative losses and make 
the physical system more efficient, to enable recovery of O&M cost by the end of the Program.  
 
70. 
A set of feasible user charges and taxes has been proposed to cover 50% of the O&M 
costs  of  a  sample  subproject  by  2010-11.  Key  actions  required  to  meet  these  levels  of  cost 
recovery will include public awareness programs, detailed enumeration of consumers, creation 
of a property registry, computerization, establishment of a regulatory commission, and capacity 
building of the municipal corporations. However, even with the levy of user charges as proposed 
and other arrangements to improve management of services and reduce losses, subprojects will 
continue  to  depend  on  government  subsidies  for  O&M  until  cost  recovery  can  be  achieved 
towards the end of the Program. 
 

2. 

Poverty Reduction and Social Impact 

 
71. 
According  to  statistics  from  the  Government  and  the  state,  the  percentage  of  the 
population  living  below  the  poverty  line  (BPL)  in  J&K  is  one  of  the  lowest15 in  the  country. 
However, in terms of access to basic social services, J&K lags behind most of the other states 
as  a  result  of  limited  investment  and  O&M  funding.  According  to  the  2001  census  of  India, 
almost 30% of the population of Jammu and Srinagar lives in slums with poor levels of services, 
particularly  sanitation.  Piped  water  is  available  to  only  about  8%  of  the  populations  of  Jammu 
and Srinagar. However, the levels of services provided are poor, with only 1–2 hours per day in 
many  areas,  at  low  pressure.  About  40%  of  the  solid  waste  in  Jammu  and  30%  in  Srinagar 
remains uncollected and is disposed of indiscriminately into local drains, streams, and rivers.  
 
An initial poverty reduction and social assessment undertaken during the preparation of 
72. 
the  investment  program  in  the  two  cities  indicated  a  considerable  range  between  high-  and 
low-income  groups.  Of  the  2,339  households  interviewed,  5%  comprised  households  living 
below  the  poverty  line  (BPL),  earning  less  than  Rs420  a  month.  The  cities  of  Jammu  and 
Srinagar both reflect a near-equal incidence of BPL households. The Program is not intended 
as  a  poverty  reduction  intervention,  but  it  will  contribute  considerably  to  enhancing  the  overall 
socioeconomic status of the BPL households in the participating cities and towns by improving 
and  expanding  the  coverage  of  urban  services,  as  well  as  indirect  benefits  through  improved 
public  health,  living  conditions,  quality  of  life,  and  economic  opportunities.  A  summary  poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 7. 
 

a. 

Gender 

 
73. 
J&K  ranks  25th  on  the  Gender  Disparity  Index  (GDI)  with  a  value  of  0.740  when 
compared  with  the  national  average.16 There  are  900  females  for  every  1,000  males  (2001 
census).  The  state  has  a  literacy  rate  of  54.46%—65.75%  for  males  and  41.82%  for  females 
(2001  census).  Women,  particularly  among  the  poor,  and  children  end  up  with  the  main 
responsibility  in  the  household  for  fetching,  storing,  and  using  water  for  washing  and  cooking. 
They  spend  at  least  1  hour  per  day  collecting  water  and  sometimes  twice  as  long.  A 
fundamental  direct  beneficiary  of  the  water  supply  component  will  be  the  BPL  portion  of  this 
gender group. The provision of sanitation and drainage facilities will also improve public health 
                                                 
15 Government of India, Planning Commission, 2001. National Human Development Report, 2001. New Delhi, India. 
16 India with a GDI value of 0.574 ranks 103rd in the world (UNDP Human Development Indicators, 2003). 
 

 

 20 

 

and hygiene, a major area of concern, while the road component will provide better access to 
economic activity centers and to educational and medical facilities.  
 

b. 

HIV/AIDS 

 
74. 
The statistics of the National AIDS Control Organization for 2005 show that close to 5.2 
million people, or around 0.4% of the country’s population, are infected with HIV. In November 
2002,  there  were  about  24,000  cases  of  HIV  infection  in  J&K  (0.2%  of  the  state’s  population, 
according to the J&K AIDS Control Society), meaning it is a low-prevalence state with regard to 
the disease. HIV is commonly found among migrant laborers, truck drivers, and security forces. 
Given the current level of transmission of the disease in J&K, the AIDS Control Society in the 
state has made it a priority to increase public awareness of HIV. 
 

c. 

Indigenous People 

 
75. 
J&K is home to 11 major tribes as well as a number of smaller indigenous groups and 
constitute  a  significant  proportion  of  the  population  in  the  Rajouri,  Udhampur,  Poonch,  Uri, 
Ganderbal,  Anantnag,  Daksum,  and  Kandi  areas  of  Jammu.  However,  since  the  project  is 
mainly  urban,  only  a  very  limited  number  of  indigenous  peoples  were  noted  during  the  initial 
poverty  and  social  assessments.  The  indigenous  peoples  households  covered  during  the 
surveys in the project areas were largely assimilated with the local population.  
 
76. 
The  investment  program  will  not  hinder  or  adversely  affect  any  segment  of  the 
population of ethnic origin. On the other hand, it will benefit equally all persons in the investment 
program  area.  All  subprojects  under  the  Program,  particularly  those  in  the  towns  where  there 
may  be  some  impact  in  subsequent  tranches,  will  be  supported  by  the  indigenous  peoples 
development  plan  prepared  according  to  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  People  (1998)  and  the 
agreed indigenous people’s development framework (Supplementary Appendix C).  
 

d. 

Land Acquisition and Involuntary Resettlement 

 
77. 
The Program incorporates minimization of land acquisition and involuntary resettlement. 
Of  the  4  subprojects  appraised,  two  subprojects 17  entail  land  acquisition  and  involuntary 
resettlement. RPs have been prepared for these subprojects (Supplementary Appendixes C and 
D) on the basis of an agreed entitlement framework in Appendix 8. Any RPs required for future 
subprojects will be prepared according to ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy based on this   
framework. The ERA will ensure that, for subprojects involving resettlement or land acquisition, 
construction activities and relocation of affected people (APs) begin only after all APs have been 
compensated  according  to  the  agreed  RPs.  If  any  changes  made  in  the  subproject  design 
during implementation affect other persons or alter the impact on previously identified APs, the 
RP  will  be  updated  and  implemented  in  a  manner  satisfactory  to  ADB.  All  RPs  under  the 
Program will be translated into the local language and distributed among the affected people by 
the ERA. The RPs will also be posted on the ADB and ERA websites. 
 
To  ensure  the  speedy  acquisition  of  land  under  the  Program,  a  high-powered 
78. 
committee18 will be formed at the state or ERA level for the independent valuation of land based 
on its current market replacement value. The committee will also establish, on the basis of the 
prevailing rates, the transitional allowance and assistance to be provided to APs to restore their

3. 

Environmental Assessment 

 
79. 
Following  the  IEEs  of  the  4  subprojects  and  ADB’s  review,  Project  1  was  classified  as 
environment  category  B–sensitive,  according  to  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  (2002).  The  most 
urgently required improvements and their readiness to proceed were considered in the selection 
of the 4 subprojects in Project 1. Based on their IEEs, 3 subprojects are category B, by virtue of 
their  actual  physical  impact,  but  the  solid  waste  disposal  site  in  Srinagar  is  classified  as  B-
sensitive.  
 
80. 
The subprojects in Project 1 will not have any significant adverse environmental impacts.  
The  ERA  will  be  responsible  for  ensuring  that  the  PMUs  implement  the  environmental 
management plans (EMP) developed as part of the IEEs are incorporated as line items in the 
related tender and contract documents. 
 
81. 
Some  subprojects  in  subsequent  tranches  may  be  encroaching  on  wildlife  sanctuaries 
and  other  environmentally  sensitive  areas  and  may  accordingly  be  classified  as  environment 
category A. Such subprojects may be developed after the master plans for the respective towns 
are completed and maps for wild life sanctuaries and forest areas are updated and available. In 
addition,  any  works  that  encroach  on  the  sanctuaries  will  require  that  ERA  obtain  all  the 
necessary  statutory  clearances.  Subprojects  that  fall  under  environment  category  A  will  be 
eligible  for  financing  under  the  MFF  subject  to  ADB’s  prior  approval  and  classification.  The 
summary  EIA  (SEIA)  or  summary  IEE  (SIEE)  for  A  and  B-sensitive  subprojects  must  be 
disclosed  to  the  public  120  days  prior  to  submission  to  ADB  for  approval.  No  subproject  will 
encroach on any national park or its buffer zone. If any changes occur in specific locations or 
alignments  of  infrastructure  or  project  facilities  after  the  IEE  or  EIA,  or  any  new  information 
becomes  available  that  have  additional  environmental  impacts,  then  the  IEE  or  EIA  will  be 
updated by ERA and approved by ADB before contracts are awarded. The ERA will submit to 
ADB  twice-yearly  progress  reports  on  the  implementation  of  the  EMPs  and  the  environmental 
monitoring  carried  out  as  a  regular  part  of  project  implementation.  All  documents  on 
environmental  issues,  including  EIAs,  SEIAs,  IEEs,  SIEEs,  and  progress  reports,  will  be 
properly  recorded  and  maintained  as  part  of  the  Program  and  made  available  to  the  public, 
according to ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005). Future subprojects will conform to the 
environmental assessment and review framework (EARF) in Supplementary Appendix D. 
 
 
 
82. 
Policy Risks. The state’s economy is reviving after 2 decades stagnation. The municipal 
corporations  in  Srinagar  and  Jammu  have  only  recently  been  formed—the  first  municipal 
elections were held in June 2005—and at this stage of their development are reluctant, and do 
not  yet  have  the  human  resources,  to  accept  the  responsibilities  envisaged  in  the  state’s 
devolution  plan  and  the  related  reform  agenda.  The  city  residents  are  used  to  almost  free

Risks  

4.

services,  albeit  at  poor  levels.  The  newly  elected  councils  may  therefore  be  reluctant  to 
implement  consumption-based  water  charges  and  introduce  property  taxes.  Water  users  may 
resist  the  charges  and  also  hesitate  to  connect  to  the  new  sewerage  network  because  of  the 
higher  water  fees  that would  entail.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  extensive  awareness  and 
capacity-building programs, and the provision of better services which with an extensive public 
awareness  programs  should  ease  concerns.  The  implementation  schedule  takes  into  account 
the  need  to  first  improve  the  available  services  before  increasing  user  charges.  The  8-year 
Program will allow enough time to achieve the reforms.  
 
83. 
Location  Risks.  The  ongoing  project  has  experienced  some  problems  due  to  the 
relative  remote  location  of  the  project  area.  Many  contractors  from  outside  the  state  are 
participating in tenders. Most people in the area and the Srinagar valley welcome the project as 
a much-needed improvement of basic facilities and promoting economic development, and they 
seem to appreciate the value of ADB’s requirement for transparency, open procurement, quality 
control,  capacity  building,  reporting,  and  audits.  Nevertheless, 
the  proposed  Program 
recognizes  that  there  may  be  special  needs  in  the  State  to  counter  any  incidents  and 
to  provide  good 
disruptions.  The  ERA  will  advise  all  consultants  and  contractors 
communications,  secure  living  and  working  conditions  and  location  allowances  to  attract  and 
keep  experienced  personnel.  The  ERA  will  follow  the  quality-based  procedure  for  recruiting 
project  consultants  to  better  incorporate  such  considerations  in  the  contracts  to  avoid  the 
problems  experienced  on  the  ongoing  project.  Similarly,  the  ERA  will  consult  all  stakeholders 
when planning and appraising new subprojects, issue regular progress reports in local-language 
newspapers, and hire independent monitors as required to facilitate consultations, disseminate 
project activities and benefits. The ADB-funded TA consultants will continue to support the ERA.  
 
84. 
Design  and  Implementation  Risks.  Experience  on  the  ongoing  project  indicates  that 
competent consultants may be better recruited individually rather than through firms and this is 
incorporated in the procedures. Firms may be hired through quality and costs or quality based 
procedures.  To  reduce  costs  and  improve  efficiency  the  ERA  may  allow  routine  design  and 
drawings to be prepared in the consultants’ offices outside the state.  
 
J&K  is  in  an  earthquake-prone  region, 20  raising  the  risk  of  physical  damage  to 
85. 
infrastructure  in  a  major  earthquake.  This  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  requiring  all  engineering 
designs to meet Indian standards for earthquake-resistant buildings in earthquake zones 4 and 
5. The Program will also evaluate the viability of retrofitting public buildings such as schools and 
hospitals, to protect the life and property of the inhabitants and users of these buildings, as well 
as to demonstrate good practices in disaster preparedness to private sector builders.  
 
86. 
Safeguards  Risks. Environmental and social risks will be mitigated through the use of 
appropriate filters as part of subproject selection and appraisal, as described above. There is a 
high degree of awareness of the need to protect the pristine areas and general environment of 
the state, one of the reasons the State wanted ADB involved.

Government of India, the state, and ERA will ensure that:

A  high-powered  committee  will  be  established  at  the  state  level  within  1

the  affected  persons  (Appendix  8:  Resettlement 
Framework).  This  committee  will  make  independent  valuation  of  land  on 
the  basis  of  its  replacement  value.  Negotiations,  if  any,  will  be  voluntary 
and devoid of any coercion. The participation or representation of APs or 
other representatives will be mandatory in all negotiations. Minutes of all 
negotiations  covering  the  key  points  of  discussion  and  outcomes  will  be 
maintained  by  ERA.  In  addition,  the  committee  will  establish  the 
transitional allowances  in  accordance  with  the  RP  and  the  assistance to 
be  provided  to  APs  on  the  basis  of  the  prevailing  rates  to  restore 
livelihoods to pre-project levels.

the  implementation  of  the  resettlement  plan  and  the  indigenous  peoples 
development plan (if any).

3. 

HIV/AIDS and Human Trafficking and Labor  

 
92. 
The state through ERA will ensure that the civil works contractors under the Program will 
follow all applicable labor laws of the Government and the State shall incorporate provisions to 
the effect that the contractors will (i) carry out HIV/AIDS awareness programs for labor; (ii) not 
employ  or  use  children  as  labor;  (iii)  disseminate  information  at  work  sites  on  the  risks  of 
sexually  transmitted  diseases  and  HIV/AIDS,  as  part  of  health  and  safety  measures  for  those 
employed  during  construction;  and  (iv)  follow  and  implement  all  statutory  provisions  on  labor 
(including equal pay for equal work), health, safety, welfare, sanitation, and working conditions. 
The civil works contracts will also provide for termination of the contract by the state or ERA in 
case of breach of any of the stated provisions by the contractors.

RECOMMENDATION 

94. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  multitranche  financing  facility  would  comply  with  the 
Articles of Agreement of the ADB and recommend that the Board approve the provision of loans 
from  the  multitranche  financing  facility  in  an  aggregate  principal  amount  not  exceeding 
$300,000,000  equivalent  to  India  for  the  Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector  Development 
Investment  Program  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as 
are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  Framework  Financing  Agreement 
presented to the Board.

IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS AND SUB PROJECT SELECTION CRITERIA 

Implementation Arrangements 

A. 
 
Economic Reconstruction Agency (ERA) will be the Executing Agency for the Investment 
1. 
Program and responsible for overall strategic guidance, technical supervision and work quality 
and  ensuring  compliance  with  loan  and  periodic  finance  request  (PFR)  provisions  and  due 
diligence. The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of ERA will report to the Governing body chaired 
by the Minister for Planning of the State. Two Project Management Units (PMU) under ERA, are 
already  established  in  Srinagar  and  Jammu,  with  each  PMU  headed  by  a  full-time  Project 
Director,  reporting  to  the  CEO.  The  Project  Directors,  will  be  supported  by  PMU  staff 
comprising,  water  supply,  sewerage,  solid  waste  management,  urban  transportation,  financial 
and    economic  analysts,  procurement,  social  development,  environmental  and  procurement 
specialists and project advisory consultants. A senior officer, directly reporting to the CEO and 
supported by institutional, financial and municipal management specialists and consultants will 
also  be  appointed  to  oversee  the  institutional  development  and  capacity  building  program. 
Another senior officer, reporting directly to the CEO will be appointed for ensuring compliance 
with  environmental  and  social  safeguards  policies.  Each  PMU  will  have  a  dedicated 
Financial/Accounts officer to look after the project accounts and processing claims. 
 
The PMUs will be responsible for the identification, formulation and implementation of all 
2. 
sub-projects  including  ensuring  conformance  with  state,  national  and  ADB  social  and 
environmental safeguards policies. Staff on deputation from the line agencies/ municipalities or 
recruited  from  the  market,  under  the  direction  of  the  Project  Director  of  each  PMU  will  be 
responsible  for  the  day  to  day  implementation  of  the  multi  tranche  financing  facility  (MFF) 
including  detailed  planning  and  design,  tendering,  construction  supervision,  quality  control, 
processing  and  checking  of  contractors’  progress  claims  and  reporting.  A  City  Level  Steering 
Committee  will  coordinate  activities  with  the  agencies  at  the  city  level  and  will  also  be 
responsible for dissemination of information to the public.  
 
3. 
Operation  and  Maintenance:  Current  practice  in  the  State,  is  for  the  Public  Health 
Engineering  Department  (PHED)  and  Urban  Environmental  Engineering  Department  (UEED) 
respectively, to operate and maintain the water and sewerage systems for all towns and Jammu 
and Srinagar cities. The new and improved water and sewerage facilities will be operated and 
managed by PHED and UEED, respectively in the short term.

B. 

Selection Criteria and Approval Process for Subprojects 

4. 
Selection  of  Component:  The  facility  will  support  the  cities  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar, 
and  other  participating  towns  and  commercial  centers  in  developing  basic  urban  services:  (i) 
water supply, (ii) sewerage and drainage, (iii) solid waste management (iv) urban transport and 
(v) other urban/ municipal infrastructure. These services together with Institutional development 
and Implementation assistance have been amalgamated into 6 components as follows: 
 

(i) 
(ii) 
(iii) 
(iv) 
(v) 
(vi) 

Component A: Water Supply; 
Component B: Sewerage and Drainage; 
Component C: Solid Waste management; 
Component D: Urban Transport; 
Component E: Other urban/municipal infrastructure; 
Component F: Capacity Building, Institutional development Governance and  

Investment Program Support  

 
Components  A,  B,  C,  D,  and  F  will  commence  early  in  the  Investment  Program  while 
5. 
Components  E  will  be  not  be  undertaken  until  completion  of  the  Economic  Opportunity 
Development Plan/Master Plan of the sub-sector.  
 
6. 
meet the following eligibility criteria: 
 
7. 

Eligibility Criteria for Subprojects: The MFF would finance only those subprojects, which 

Technical Criteria: 

 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

The  subproject  will  be  part  of  sub-sector  Master  Plan  to  be  prepared  under  the 
ongoing  loan  2151  IND,  and  any  subsequent  changes  thereafter,  with  priority 
given to strengthening and optimum utilization of the existing system.  

The  subproject  will  be  technically  sound  and  preliminary  design  will  have  been 
prepared.  The  subproject  will  be  designed  and  executed  as  seismic  resistant 
structure in accordance with relevant standards. 

All necessary central and state government approvals will be in place. 

The nature of subproject eligible for inclusion in the program are: 

1. 
Water  Supply.  Work  relating  to  improvement  of  transmission  mains, 
distribution networks, balancing reservoirs, pumping stations, consumer metering 
and if required, augmentation of water supply source. Priority should be given to 
expansion  of  the  water  supply  network  to  uncovered  areas  of  the  cities, 
improvement  of  the  distribution  networks  and  proposals  aiming  at  reduction  of 
unaccounted for water. 

2. 
Sewerage  and  Drainage.  Works  relating  to  laying  of  sewer  networks, 
pumping  stations,  sewerage  treatment  plants,  public  toilets,  house  connection, 
construction  of  community  septic  tank,  sewer  cleaning  equipments  and  septic 
tank emptier. 

Sewerage sub-projects should limited to the densely populated areas with 
adequate per capita water supply to ensure that self-cleansing velocities 
can be achieved on a regular basis without frequent system flushing.

Sewerage sub-projects will only commence once sample surveys show a
