All  the  subprojects  proposal  for  laying  of  sewer  network  should  have  a 
component of house service connection. 

Sewer  and  septic  tank  cleaning  equipments  will  only  be  procured  once 
the  states  have  developed  secured  land  fill  site  for  solid  waste 
management for the city. 

Only  the  lakes  in  the  cities  which  suffer  from  significant  degradation 
and/or solid waste deposition will be included in the programs.    

Solid  Waste  Management  (SWM).  Works  pertaining  to  improvement  of 

3. 
collection, transportation, segregation and disposal of municipal waste. 

SWM subproject should be limited to only Municipal Waste; proposal for 
hazardous or biomedical waste will not be eligible for financing under this 
program. 

SWM equipments and vehicles will only be procured once the urban local 
bodies have developed secured land fill site for solid waste management 
for the city. 

Proposal  for  composting  plant  under  the  SWM  component  should  be 
supported  by  the  market  analysis  of  demand  of  end  product  and  the 
financial viability of the plants. 

All  compost  plant  proposals  should  be  based  on  private  public 
partnership.  

4. 
Urban  Transport.  Works  related  to  improvement  of  riding  quality, 
reduction of traffic congestion, widening of existing roads, Bypass arrangements, 
car parking arrangements and improvement of pedestrian facilities. 

(a)  Work  is  limited  to  internal  roads,  and  National  Highways  are  excluded 

from the MFF. 

(b)  Works related to Mass transit system are also excluded from the MFF. 

Other Municipal/urban Infrastructure  

Support for works relating to area development/commercial infrastructure 
will be only to those identified by the Economic Opportunity Development 
Plan/ Master Plan.  

Proposals  for  construction  of  slaughter  houses  will  be  conditional  to  the 
establishment of waste treatment and disposal facilities. 

Other works relating to obligatory municipal functions will be subject to a 
situation  report  and  within  a  road  map  for  improvements  in  the  service 
functions. 

 
8. 
Financial  and  Institutional  Criteria.  Sub-projects  must  demonstrate  financial  and 
institutional  sustainability;  this  will  be  demonstrated  by  a  5  year  horizon  business  plan  that 
targets  100%  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  cost  recovery  by  the  end  of  the  Investment 
Program. The business plan must  address O&M cost, sources of funds i.e, State  support and 
user charges, O&M staffing needs and service level targets agreed with the urban local bodies. 

 46     Appendix 5  

 

The  business  plans  must  also  describe  the  institutional  arrangements  for  implementation  and 
handover of the sub projects from ERA to the service providing agency. 
 
9. 
Economic Criteria. The sub-project must be part of the overall master plan for the sub 
sector and it should have an economic internal rate of return of at least 12% or it should be the 
least cost technical option of providing the particular service. 
 
10. 
The  project  should  have  adequate  arrangements  to  implement  the  project  and  the 
operation and maintenance team should be in place including financial allocation as part of the 
municipal budget.  
 
11. 
Social Criteria. The subproject will, to the extent possible, not require land acquisition or 
resettlement  (which  includes  the  displacement  of  squatters  or  encroachers  from  the  rights  of 
way). If land acquisition or involuntary resettlement is required for a subproject, a Resettlement 
Plan  will  be  prepared  and  implemented  in  accordance  with  applicable  laws  and  regulations  of 
the State Government, ADB’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement and the agreed Resettlement 
Framework (Appendix 8). 
 
12. 
If  any  indigenous  peoples/scheduled  tribes  are  likely  to  be  affected  significantly  by  a 
subproject,  an  Indigenous  People  Development  Plan  will  be  prepared  and  implemented  in 
accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  People  (1998)  and  the  agreed  Indigenous 
People’s Development Framework (Supplementary Appendix C) 
 
13. 
Environmental  Criteria.  The  subprojects  will  comply  with  environmental  requirements 
specified  in  ADB’s  Environment  Policy  2002  and  those  specified  in  Country’s  environmental 
regulations,  including  legislations  and  standards  of  the  Government  of  Jammu  and  Kashmir. 
Environmental assessment of individual sub project will be carried out and mitigation measures 
identified  during  the  assessment  will  be  implemented  in  accordance  with  Environmental 
Assessment and Review Framework (Supplementary Appendix D) of the Investment Program.

Feasibility study, for all subprojects to be considered under the respective Loans,

Based  on  the  categorization  and  upon  completion  of  the  detailed  engineering

considered  under  the  respective  Loans  following  the  selection  criteria,  together

with form of periodic financing agreement to ADB for approval. However, if any of

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY (SPRSS) 

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

Is the sector identified as a

poverty analysis?

 Yes

Contribution of the sector or subsector to the reduction of poverty in India: 
The Program is primarily designed to improve urban infrastructure and services in the two principal cities of 
Jammu  and  Srinagar  and  in  selected  tourist  centers  in  Jammu  and  Kashmir  state.  It  will  also  build  local 
capability to run and manage the facilities.  
 
Both Jammu and Srinagar have witnessed large-scale migration from rural areas, mostly driven by security 
concerns  over  the  last  decades;  consequently,  the  infrastructure  is  highly  stressed.  By  providing  urban 
infrastructure  and  services  particularly  in  underserved  areas,  the  Program  will  improve  access  to  services 
and  contribute  to  urban  development,  the  overall  enhancement  of  the  quality  of  life,  and  the  reduction  of 
poverty in the two cities.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                           Targeting Classification:  General Intervention 

What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
Sample subprojects for project preparation were selected from each of the four major urban components—
water supply, sewerage, solid waste management, and urban transport. Two of the four sample subprojects 
are in Jammu and the other two in Srinagar.  
 
A sample socioeconomic baseline survey was undertaken in the two cities among a representative sample 
of 2,339 households. Eight-five percent of the households considered the Program beneficial and expected 
improvements  in  the  lives  of  the  local  residents. The  rest  felt  that  the  Program  would  have  limited  impact. 
Five percent of the households were below the poverty line (BPL) with a per capita income of Rs420.20 per 
month  and  with  limited  access  to  urban  services,  according  to  the  National  Human  Development  Report 
(2001). This percentage figure is higher than the 1.98% mentioned in state-level urban BPL statistics. The 
incidence of BPL households is almost the same in Jammu and Srinagar. The mean household income of 
BPL  households  is  about  Rs2,000  per  month.  BPL  households  also  considered  the  Program  particularly 
beneficial to them if implemented. 
 
The overall direct benefits from the Program will come from improvements in basic service provision in the 
beneficiary areas. Residents will benefit from improved living conditions, a healthier living environment, and 
the prospect of improved health.  
 
In  addition,  the  selection  of  subprojects  under  the  Program  is  based  on  social  and  poverty  indicators 
applicable  in  the  urban  context  and  on  the  limited  access  of  the  poor  to  basic  urban  services.  The  low-
income  group  with  limited  access  to  urban  services  stands  to  benefit  from  better  access  to  better-quality 
services.   
 
C.  Participation Process 

 
  Yes 
  Yes 

  No 
  No 

Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
As part of the initial poverty and social assessment study during Program preparation, discussions were held 
with Program beneficiaries, namely, local residents, local resident welfare committees, and most importantly 
women in the communities. Particular attention was paid to ensuring the participation of socioeconomically 
vulnerable  groups  and  BPL  households  in  the  process.  Separate  focus  group  discussions  were  held  with 
these groups to get their views and opinions on the Program.  
 
All  these  discussions  were  aimed  primarily  at  (i)  informing  the  communities  and  the  people  about  the 
proposed  Program;  (ii)  getting  wider  public  input  and  suggestions  from  stakeholders  on  the  Program, 
particularly their priority needs with regard to the sector; and (iii) assessing the current role and functions of 
the local residents’ organizations.  

  
58       Appendix 7 

 
These discussions and consultations confirmed the need for the Program, with all socioeconomic groups in 
the community responding positively to it. The key benefits of the Program, according to the stakeholders, 
are : (i) improved cleanliness  and hygiene, and reduction  in  waterborne diseases; (ii) improved health; (iii) 
better  services  and  less  drudgery  involved  in  collecting  water  and  gaining  access  to  other  services, 
particularly  for  women;  (iv)  less  likelihood  of  flooding  and,  hence,  reduced  expenditure  on  repair  and 
maintenance of property; and (v) improved living conditions and a healthier living environment.  
 
A  community  participation  strategy  (Supplementary  Appendix  F)  has  been  prepared  for  the  Program  to 
ensure the participation of the community (including women) in Program planning and implementation.  
D.  Gender and Development 

An attempt was made during the IPSA to understand gender-specific roles, status, needs, and problems in 
the  two  cities  through  gender  analysis.  Attempts  were  also  made  to  ascertain  the  gender  impacts  of  the 
Program  through  focus  group  discussions  with  women  from  different  socioeconomic  groups  in  the 
subproject  areas.  These  discussions  were  held  to  capture  women’s  collective  perceptions  about  social, 
economic,  and  cultural  norms  and  their  access  to  facilities,  and  the  results  were  further  substantiated 
through participatory rural appraisal exercises.  
 
The  improvement  of  urban  services,  particularly  water  supply  and  sanitation,  according  to  the  women 
participants, will have far-reaching impact on them and their lives. The women participants in both cities said 
that the project would empower them by giving them greater access to services and resources. A key benefit 
they  identified  was  the  reduced  time  that  would  be  required  for  health  maintenance  and  care  giving, 
particularly  with  the  water  supply  improvements,  giving  them  more  time  for  productive  endeavors, 
empowerment  activities,  and  leisure.  Better  urban  services,  and  particularly  better  city  roads,  according  to 
most  of  the  women  participants,  would  give  them  greater  access  to  resources  such  as  medical  facilities, 
schools, and transportation. The indirect benefit of the Program to women would be a healthier and cleaner 
environment, thereby contributing to a better quality of life overall.

Appendix 8      61

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 

Description of the Project   

A. 
 
Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector  Development  Investment  Program  (JKUSDIP)  is 
1. 
under  preparation  as  a  sector  loan  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  for  improving 
infrastructure  and  municipal  services  in  two  municipal  corporations  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar 
cities and selected tourist centres1 and other important towns, within Jammu and Kashmir State. 
The Project will include investment in physical infrastructure plus proposals for capacity building 
and institutional strengthening of city and state authorities. 
 
2. 
In  order  to  prepare  and  process  the  Project  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  procedures  for 
sector lending, a set of four subprojects have been selected one each in each of the four major 
urban  sub-sectors  namely  –  Water  Supply,  Sewerage,  Solid  Waste  Management  and  Urban 
Transport  in  the  two  cities  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar.  In  keeping  with  ADB’s  sector  loan 
procedures;  this  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared  to  set  out  the  resettlement  policy 
and  screening  and  planning  procedures  that  will  apply  to  subprojects,  components,  or 
investments  that  are  prepared  and  approved  during  loan  implementation  to  ensure  that  they 
conform  to  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy.  The  Framework  thus,  identifies  the  broad 
scope  of  the  project  and  outlines  the  policy,  procedures  for  acquisition  of  land,  compensation 
and other assistance measures for affected persons and institutional requirements for preparing 
subsequent sub-projects under the sector loan.  
 
B. 
 
3. 
The  resettlement  principles  adopted  in  this  framework  recognize  the  State  Land 
Acquisition  (LA)  Act  1990  and  the  entitlement  benefits  as  listed  in  the  National  Policy  on 
Resettlement  and  Rehabilitation,  (Govt  of  India)  as  notified  in  February  2004  and  the  relevant 
Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  policies  and  operations  manuals,  in  particular  the  Policy  on 
Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995),  and  Operations  Manual  F2  on  Involuntary  Resettlement 
(2003).  
 
Following  the  state  laws  and  regulation  on  land  acquisition  and  incorporating  ADB 
4. 
policies  and  operations  manuals  as  well  as  the  National  Policy  on  Resettlement  and 
Rehabilitation, the basic principles for the Project will include the following elements with respect 
to each subproject:  
 

Resettlement Policy and Framework 

a)  As a matter of policy, land acquisition, and other involuntary resettlement impacts would 

be minimized as much as possible; 

b)  Any land acquisition and/or resettlement will be carried out and compensation provided in 
order  to  improve  or  at  least  restore  the  pre-Project  income  and  living  standards  of  the 
affected people; 

c)  Consultation  with  affected  people  on  compensation  options  and  preparation 

Resettlement Plan (RP) in accordance with this Framework; 

d)  Payment of compensation for acquired assets at market/replacement rates; 
e)  Payment of compensation for lost land, housing, assets and resettlement allowances in 
full  prior  to  the  contractor  taking  physical  acquisition  of  the  land  and  prior  to    the 
commencement of any construction activities; 

                                                 
1  The  towns  initially  selected  for  consideration  are  Patnitop  (Jammu  region),  Gulmarg,  Pahalgam  and  Sonamarg 

(Kashmir region). 

 62 

     Appendix 8 

f)  All compensation and other assistances2 will be paid to all affected people (AP) prior to 

commencement of civil works.  

g)  Income restoration and rehabilitation; 
h)  An entitlement matrix (Table-1) for different categories of people affected by the project 
has  been  prepared  and  provisions  will  be  kept  in  the  budget  for  those  who  were  not 
present at the time of census survey. However, people moving in the project area after 
the cut-off date will not be entitled to any assistance. In case of land acquisition the date 
of notification for acquisition will be treated as cut-off date. For non-titleholders such as 
squatters and encroachers the date of project census survey or a similar designated date 
declared by the executing agency will be considered as cut-off date. "  and 

i)  Special attention to vulnerable groups. 

Procedures for Resettlement Plan (RP) Preparation 

 
C. 
 
5. 
undertaken by the Program Management Units in keeping with the following:  
 

Each  subproject  will  be  prepared,  and  the  detail  design  of  each  subproject  will  be 

a)  Social  impact  assessment  surveys  including  100%  Census  survey  of  the  affected 
people,  an  asset  inventory,  landownership,  usage  and  productivity  assessments  and 
data  on  the  existing  economic  and  social  condition  of  the  affected  people  including  a 
poverty assessment and a survey of atleast 10% of the affected people and 20% of the 
seriously affected people, together with local-level impact data;  

b)  If impacts are found to be “significant,”3 a full RP will be prepared  for each subproject for 

approval prior to award of contracts for that subproject;   

c)  If  subproject  impacts  are  less  than  significant,  a  short  RP  will  be  prepared  for  that 

subproject for approval prior to award of contracts for that subproject; and  

d)  The  RP  would  also  include  measures  to  ensure  that  socio-economic  condition,  needs 
and  priorities  of  women  are  identified  and  that  the  process  of  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement does not disadvantage women.   

 
6. 
The  RP  prepared  for  the  subproject  will  be  used  as  a  model  for  the  preparation  of 
subsequent  RPs.  The  RPs  shall  comply  with  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  and 
other social safeguard guidelines. The additional full or short RPs will be disclosed to the APs, 
endorsed by the executing agency and will be submitted to ADB for approval prior to award of 
civil works contracts for a subproject. The full RP, not just the summary will be disclosed to the 
APs as well as uploaded on the ADB website after ADB review and approval. In case impacts 
on Indigenous People are identified, then appropriate mitigative actions for them depending on 
the magnitude of the Project impacts and sensitivity of IP issues will be undertaken in the form 
of  either  preparation  of  a  full  Indigenous  People’s  Development  Plan  (IPDP)  or  integration  of 

                                                 
2 While compensation is required prior to dispossession or displacement of affected people from their assets, the full 
resettlement plan implementation, which may require income rehabilitation measures, might be completed only over 
a  longer  period  of  time  after  civil  works  have  begun.  Affected  people  will  be  provided  with  certain  resettlement 
entitlements,  such  as  land  and  asset  compensation  and  transfer  allowances,  prior  to  their  displacement, 
dispossession, or restricted access. 
3  Source: Asian Development Bank Operations Manual –Operational Procedure on Involuntary Resettlement  
Involuntary Resettlement Category A: Significant means 200 or more people will experience major impacts, which 
are  defined  as  (i)  being  physically  displaced  from  housing,  or  (ii)  losing  10%  or  more  of  their  productive  assets 
(income generating). Categories A projects require a full resettlement plan. Some of these projects may require a 
resettlement  framework  prior  to  the  full  resettlement  plan.  Involuntary  Resettlement  Category  B:  Not  Significant 
include  involuntary  resettlement  impacts  that  are  not  deemed  significant  and  require  a  short  resettlement  plan. 
Some of these projects may require a resettlement framework prior to the short resettlement plan.

Established  in  each  main  project  city,  the  PMU  will  have  the  primary  responsibility  of  the 
preparation of RPs and their implementation. The Design & Supervision Consultants (DSC) will 
assist  the  PMU  in  meeting  the  safeguard  requirements  as  agreed  in  the  loan  covenant  and 
preparation of the subproject RPs in keeping with the agreed Resettlement Framework for the 
Project.

for each subproject, and for monitoring any changes to subproject design which may require re-

part of the Project for assisting in implementation of RP. A Resettlement Officer  at the PMU will

Grievance  Redressal  and  monitoring  of  resettlement  operation.  The  PMU  will  ensure

NGOs for timely RP implementation.

This Financing Framework Agreement (“FFA”) dated 17 April 2007 is between 
India acting by its President (“India”) and Asian Development Bank (“ADB”).  
 
India has requested on behalf of the State of Jammu and Kashmir, the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  finance  the  Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector 
the 
(JKUSDIP) 
Development 
roadmap/investment plan described in Schedule 1 hereto. 
 
Context: 
 
India  and  the  State  are  committed  to  and  will  implement  the  Roadmap  and 
Investment  Program  described  in  Schedule  1  hereto.  The  Roadmap  and 
Investment Program aims to improve the urban environment, public health and 
economic  opportunities  for  the  2.4  million  urban  residents  in  J&K.  It  will  also 
indirectly  benefit  the  State’s  rural  population  of  9.6  million  people  through 
improved economic opportunities.  This will be achieved through expansion of 
basic municipal services to meet the service standards of India in the State’s 
principal  cities  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar  and  other  economically  important 
towns,  including  several  that  have  excellent  potential  for  increased  tourism 
investment by the private sector. The proposed Investment Program builds on 
the  ongoing  Loan  2151-IND:  Multi-sector  Project 
Infrastructure 
Rehabilitation  in  Jammu  and  Kashmir.1  This  ongoing  project  is  limited  to 
rehabilitation  of  key  urban  infrastructure  in  Jammu  and  Srinagar  and  about 
2000  kilometers  of  rural  roads  to  improve  access  and  connectivity,  but  does 
not  include  expansion  of  facilities,  except  as  in  the  normal  course  of 
rehabilitation.  
   
The maintenance of existing infrastructure and expansion to meet the ongoing 
population growth has been inadequate. The State and the India have agreed 
to  address  these  deficiencies  through  a  major  Investment  Program  based  on 
the 10th 5-Year Plan, combined with the 11th 5-Year Plan and the related road 
map developed for the Investment Program as depicted in Schedule 1. Much 
of  the  proposed  investments  in  water  supply,  sanitation  and  transportation 
access will benefit the urban poor, who live without adequate water supply or 
sanitation. In particular, the sewerage and drainage improvements will improve 
the  public  health  in  the  lower  income  and  poor  sections  of  all  participating 
towns. 
 
During formulation of the proposed Investment Program there has been public 
consultations and the proposed investments have the support of stakeholders. 
In  addition,  there  has  been  extensive  policy  dialogue  with  the  State  line 
(PHED)  currently 
departments;  Public  Health  Engineering  Department 
responsible  for  water,  the  Urban  Environmental  Engineering  Department 
(UEED) responsible for sewerage and main drainage channels, Public Works 
Department  (PWD)  responsible  for  roads,  the  State  Wild  Life  and  Forestry 
Department,  the  municipal  corporations  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar  responsible

for  solid  waste  and  local  drainage,  the  mayor  and  development  authorities  of 
the  other  towns,  as  well  as  the  various  State  agencies  responsible  for  land 
use,  zoning,  building  codes  and  approvals,  new  area  development  ,  finance 
and  revenues.  The  key  policy  aspects  relate  to  the  State’s  plan  to  make  the 
Jammu and Srinagar municipal corporations autonomous entities. In addition, 
as  in  all  urban  projects  in  India,  improved  municipal  administration,  revenue 
enhancement  and  accounting  are  major  requirements  for  which  extensive 
capacity  building  and  training  of  staff  has  been  incorporated  into  the 
Investment Program.  
    
Investment Program: 
 
The total cost of J&K’s  urban sector development plan and sector strategy is 
estimated to be $2 billion, equivalent, over the period 2006 to 2026. The total 
cost  of  the  Roadmap  and  Investment  Program  supported  by  ADB’s  facility, 
from 2007 through 2015, is expected to be $485 million, equivalent.  

 

ADB’s  support  is  intended  to  help  finance  the  State’s  transactions  under  the 
Investment  Program  described  in  Schedule  1,  subject  to  the  subproject 
selection  criteria  set  out  in  Schedule  4.  The  investments  will  include 
improvements in urban infrastructure in Jammu, Srinagar and other important 
towns. The actual towns to be selected for inclusion in the Investment Program 
will  be  finalized  once  the  State’s  economic  opportunity  development  strategy 
and  related  master  plans  have  been  completed.  The  investments  will  include 
rehabilitation,  upgrading  and  expansion  of  water  supply  systems,  sewage 
collection  from  high  density  areas  with  treatment,  drainage,  solid  waste 
management  (SWM)  facilities,  urban  roads  and  bridges  including  roads 
connecting these important towns, and municipal facilities aimed at improving 
the quality of life for low income residents and poor persons through facilities 
like  public  toilets  and  baths,  fire  protection  and  local  clinics.  In  addition,  the 
Investment  Program  may  restore  key  historic  and  tourism  facilities  that  are 
essential to improve economic growth and activity.      
 
The  Investment  Program  will  also  finance  the  strengthening  of  municipal 
management  in  Jammu  and  Srinagar  including:  updating  of  property  records 
and tax rolls and records of all users of municipal services, computerization of 
all    records,  accounts,  billing  and  collection,  and  development  of  budgets  for 
Operation  and  Maintenance  (O&M).  This  will  include  provision  of  computers, 
strengthening/capacity  building  of  departments,  and  training  of  staff  in  city 
management,  formation  of  regulatory  authority  for  water  and  sewerage  and 
drainage  services,  and  training  of  technical  operating  staff  to  improve  O&M. 
The key aspects of the Facility will be set out in the Project Agreement that will 
be signed by the State.

The Multitranche Financing Facility (the Facility) is intended to finance Projects 
under the Roadmap and Investment Program, provided India and the State are 
in compliance with the understandings set out in this FFA and the constituent 
Projects  are  in  line  with  those  same  understandings  and  comply  with  the 
criteria set out in Schedule 4 of this FFA. 
 
Financing Terms: 
  
ADB  will  provide  loans  to  finance  Projects  under  the  Road  map  and 
Investment  Program, as and when the Projects are ready for financing. Each 
loan will constitute a tranche. Each loan may be financed under terms different 
from  the  financing  terms  of  previous  or  subsequent  loans.  The  choice  of 
financing  terms  will  depend  on  the  project  and  ADB’s  financing  policies,  all 
prevailing  at  the  time  the  loan  is  documented  in  a  legal  document.  Tranches 
may  be  provided  in  sequence  or  simultaneously,  and  some  may  overlap  in 
time  with  each  other.  The  proposed  tranches  are  as  per  the  table  3.2  of 
Schedule 1. 

 

Commitment charges are not payable on the Facility. They are payable only on 
financing  actually  committed  by  ADB  as  a  loan.  ADB  rules  on  commitment 
charges which are in effect when a tranche is provided, will apply with respect

to such tranche. 
 
This FFA does not constitute a legal obligation on the part of ADB to commit 
any  financing.  Financing  tranches  may  be  made  available  by  ADB  provided 
matters  continue  to  be  in  accordance  with  the  general  understandings  and 
expectations on which the Facility is based and which are laid out in this FFA. 
Likewise, this FFA does not constitute a legal obligation on the part of India to 
request  any  financing.  India  has  the  right  not  to  request  any  financing  under 
the Facility. 

 

 

India and ADB may exercise their respective rights to cancel the Facility or any 
uncommitted  portion  thereof,  and  ADB  may  exercise  its  right  to  refuse  a 
financing request, by giving written notice to such effect to the other party. The 
written notice will provide an explanation for the cancellation or refusal and, in 
the  case  of  a  cancellation,  specify  the  date  on  which  the  cancellation  takes 
effect.  Notices  under 
this  paragraph  would  be  only  after  adequate 
consultations between ADB and India. 
 
Amount: 
The maximum financing amount available under the Facility is $300 million. It 
will be provided in individual loans from ADB’s Ordinary Capital Resources5. 
 
Availability Period: 
The last date on which any disbursement under any loan may be made will be 
31 December 2015. The last Periodic Financing Request (PFR) is expected to 
be submitted no later than 31 August 2013.  

Terms and Conditions: 
Each  loan  will  be  used  to  finance  (i)  a  range  of  sub-projects  that  have  been 
appraised  and  approved  for  financing  by  ADB  for  each  loan  and  (ii)  project 
implementation  support  including  consultancy  services.  The  sub-projects 
eligibility and approval criteria are set out in Schedule 4 of this FFA. India will 
provide  the  proceeds  of  each  loan  under  the  MFF  to  the  State  on  terms  and 
conditions applicable to its own lending modalities and cause the proceeds of 
each loan to be applied to the financing of expenditures of the Roadmap and 
Investment  Program,  in  accordance  with  the  conditions  set  forth  in  this 
Agreement and the legal agreements for each loan.  
 
 
The  Executing  Agency  for  the  Projects  under  the  MFF  will  be  the  Economic 
Reconstruction Agency (ERA)6 set up by the State to implement all externally 
financed projects. ERA will implement the Roadmap and Investment Program 
in accordance with the principles set forth in Schedule 1 to this Agreement, as 
supplemented with more details in the legal agreements for each loan and in 
accordance  with  the  related  Loan  and  Project  Agreements.  The  MFF  will  be 
implemented  over  an  8  year  period.  Implementation  of  sub-projects  is

All ADB safeguard policies as amended from time to time, will apply to all the 
subprojects/components  financed  under  the  Facility.  Schedule  5  to  this 
Agreement  sets  forth  the  safeguard  frameworks  required  under  ADB’s 
safeguard  policies  and  which  India  will  require  the  State  to  comply  with  and 
implement. The safeguard requirements for each financing loan, as well as the 
categorization of each loan, will follow the approach and procedure defined in 
existing  ADB  Safeguard  Polices  and  applicable  laws  in  India  and  the  State.. 
ADB  safeguard  policies  currently  include  (i)  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995), 
(ii) Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998), and (iii) Environment Policy (2002).

Advance Contracting and Retroactive Financing: 
 
Under  each  loan  of  the  facility,  advance  contracting  of  civil  works  and 
equipment  and  materials,  and  recruitment  of  consulting  services  will  be 
proposed subject to these being eligible in accordance with agreed procedures 
and guidelines as above. 
 
Except  as  otherwise  agreed  with  ADB,  the  expenditures  incurred  for  civil 
works,  equipment  and  materials  and  consulting  services  eligible  for  advance 
action will also be eligible for retroactive financing under the first loan, provided 
that  these  are  incurred  for  a  period  no  longer  than  12  months  prior  to  the 
signing  of  the  related  loan  and  project  agreements,  and  do  not  exceed  an 
amount  equivalent  to  twenty  percent  (20%)  of  the  loan.  Retroactive  financing 
request for subsequent loans will be considered during processing of individual 
PFRs. India and the State have been advised that ADB’s approval of advance 
action  and  retroactive  financing  does  not  constitute  a  commitment  to  finance 
relevant expenditures under the facility. 
  
Loan proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement 
Handbook  (January,  2007  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To  facilitate 
Investment  Program  implementation,  India  will  establish  an  imprest  account 
and GoJ&K through ERA may establish a second generation imprest account 
(SGIA)  with  a  commercial  bank  acceptable  to  both  ADB  and  the  Borrower. 
Separate  Imprest  Account  and  SGIA  will  be  established  for  each  Loan.  The 
SGIA will be a current account. The initial and all the subsequent amounts to 
be deposited into the imprest account and into the SGIA will be determined by 
ADB  in  consultation  with  India  and  ERA,  with  particular  reference  to  the 
pipeline of awarded contracts. The draw-down will not exceed the lesser of the 
equivalent of 3 months of current project expenditures or 10% of the total loan 
amount  and  will  be  estimated  based  on  disbursements  expected  under 
contracts  over  the  next  3  months.  The  statement  of  expenditures  (SOE) 
procedure will be adopted for reimbursing and liquidating the SGIA for eligible 
expenditures  not  exceeding  $50,000  per  payment,  except  as  ADB  may 
otherwise agree during facility implementation. 
 
ERA will recruit design and supervision consultants to plan, design, supervise 
construction, maintain quality control, review and recommend progress claims 
and prepare as built drawings. They will recruit project support consultants, if 
necessary to assist ERA with managing the overall Investment Program. ERA 
will establish an Investment Program Performance Monitoring System (IPPMS) 
acceptable to ADB within 3 months of the effectiveness of the first loan under 
the MFF and under each succeeding loan. The IPPMS system will first select a 
baseline  data  for  each  of  the  selected  indicators  and  will  conduct  annual 
surveys  with  the  assistance  of  consultants  and  update  ADB  and  the 
Government  on  the  progress  against  each  indicator.  ERA  will  also  submit 
quarterly  progress  reports  in  the  format  to  be  attached  with  the  Facility 
Administration  Memorandum.  The  monitoring  reports  will  also  be  used  for 
shaping  the   subprojects to  be  developed for  succeeding  PFRs  and  loan  

 8 

 

 

Representations 
and Warranties 

tranches.  Quarterly  reviews  will  be  completed  by  the  tripartite  project  review 
meetings  chaired  by  the  Government  and  attended  by  ERA  and  ADB. 
Implementation of resettlement plans under the program will be monitored by 
independent  agency/institution  (that  may  include  established  and  registered 
NGO(s))..  The  project  accounts  will  be  audited  annually  and  submitted  for 
review  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  In  addition  to  the  regular  loan  review 
missions,  a  midterm  review  will  be  conducted  in  June  2012.  The  reviews  will 
include  a  summary  of  contracts  awards  and  disbursement,  implementation 
progress  including  progress  against  institutional  development  and  capacity 
building  milestones.  The  midterm  review  will  also  identify  problems  or 
weaknesses in implementation arrangements, and agree on changes needed. 
Within three months of physical completion of any Loan under the MFF, the EA 
will  submit  to  ADB  individual  projects  completion  report  and  a  program 
completion report, within three months of the completion of the facility.  
 
In  addition  to  standard  Representations  and  warranties,  India  through  the 
State GoJ&K, assures the following actions: 
 
Specific Representations and Warranties 

Technical.  GoJ&K  will  finalize  Master  plans  for  water  supply,  sewerage  and 
drainage,  and  solid  waste  management  before  January  2009  and  all 
engineering  structures  will  be  designed  in  accordance  with  Indian  standards 
for earthquake resistant buildings.

Counterpart  Funds.  Sufficient  counterpart  funds  by  the  GoJ&K  are  made

SCHEDULE 1: ROAD MAP AND INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

 
1. 
India’s  economy  has  strengthened  substantially  during  the  past  decade  and  considerable 
progress  in  economic  growth  has/is  being  achieved.  Indian  cities  are  the  major  engines  of  this 
growth, contributing to more than 60% of the gross domestic product (GDP). In Jammu and Kashmir 
State  (J&K),  the  State’s  economy  is  primarily  dependant  on  services,  tourism  and  trade,  and 
agriculture. There has been a shift in the contribution to the State’s GDP from the primary sectors to 
trade,  commerce  and  services.  Considered  gateways  to  the  respective  regions  and  tourist  spots, 
Jammu and Srinagar’s urban agglomerations account for over 63% of the State’s urban population. 
Following the recent reduction in disturbances in the State, tourist inflow has reached the 6.5 million 
makr, and is projected to reach 22 million by 2020. With the resurgence of the State’s economy, the 
main issue is to manage urban and economic growth and for the newly established city corporations 
in Jammu and Srinagar to be able to meet their service delivery obligations. ADB’s country strategy 
supports  the  vision  of  the  Government  to  improve  the  economy  through  infrastructure-led  growth. 
The State has already initiated improvements to basic services through the ongoing ADB financed 
urban and rural infrastructure rehabilitation project.8  
 
2. 
Recent improvement in the security situation and growth in tourisms provides the State with 
an  opportunity  to  improve  its  economy  further  but  this  will  require  urgent  improvements  in  the 
decrepit  infrastructure. The  Central  and  State Governments  are  making  a  conscious  effort  to bring 
about the much needed change. Immediate focus of the State Government is to develop the State’s 
urban  centers  as  engines  of  economic  growth.  To  achieve  this,  the  State  has  already  passed  the 
municipal  act  (2000)  creating  the  new  city  corporations  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar,  where  the  first 
elections  for  city  council  were  held  in  2005.  The  State  now  intends  to  improve  the  basic  urban 
services, particularly water and sanitation in these two cities, along with other important towns with 
tourism  growth  potential.  Concurrently,  the  State  plans  to  de-centralize  the  service  delivery 
mechanisms to the newly responsible city corporations. This will require building the capacity of the 
urban  local  bodies  and  state  line  departments  to  ensure  the  sustainability  of  infrastructure 
investments.

so than in the rest of India. The State has developed a sector road map to addresses the investment 
backlog and the need for management reforms and capacity building, and for maintaining a balance 
between the two. As part of its longer term road map, the State is seeking financial assistance from 
ADB,  in  conjunction  with  the  Jawahal  Nehru  National  Urban  Renewal  Mission  (JNNURM),  a 
Government of India (GoI) supported program for fast track, reform driven, planned development of 
63  major  towns  of  India,  including  Jammu  and  Srinagar.  The  road  map  also  contemplates 
developing  a  market  for  private  sector  participation,  initially  for  O&M  of  complicated  sewage 
treatment facilities and tourism related infrastructure. 
 
5. 
following reform initiatives: 
 

Recognizing the importance of reforming the urban sector, the State has already taken  the 

(i)  Amended  the  Municipal  Legislation  Act  and  introduced  new  acts  for  municipalities  and 
corporations (2000) and held city council elections in Jammu and Srinagar for the first time 
in 2005;  

(ii)  Constituted the State Finance Commission to strengthen state-local body relationships and 
initiate  actions  to  devolve  functions  such  as  drainage,  sewerage  and  water  supply  to  the 
local bodies; 

(iii)  Initiated capacity building program for councilors and municipal officials through  state level 

training institutes;  

(iv)  To overcome implementation capacity issues, promoted use of external experts for design 
and management of projects, as is being done for the ongoing ADB financed project, which 
will be extended to O&M of services, and 

(v)  Developed  capacity  to  plan,  design  and  implement  programs  and  cadre  related  issues 

more specifically at the municipal level.  
 
6. 
Road  Map  for  Investment.  The  State  has  prepared  a  medium  term  investment  plan  for 
urban  facilities  through  2014  and  a  longer  term  plan  through  2026.  Investments  in  physical 
infrastructure  will  be  accompanied  by  a  program  of  urban  sector  reforms  aimed  at  better 
management  of  services  and  formation  of  accountable  service  delivery  mechanism  and  financial 
autonomy through transfer of responsibility and accountability for services to the city corporations on 
a  gradual  basis  from  the  current  State  line  departments.  The  total  investment  program  under  the 
road map is summarized in Table A3.1. The estimated investment requirements will be met partially 
from the ongoing ADB financed project, the State’s ongoing “plan” expenditures, the JNNURM and 
the proposed Facility financed by ADB. The Government will use the proposed ADB investments to 
improve the public health, environment and economic opportunities of local people to help stabilize 
and  energize  the  local  economy  and  address  social  inequalities,  especially  in  the  poor  and  low 
income sectors of the population.

Investment  Program.  The  proposed  Investment  Program  will  be  implemented  over  an  8 
year period through 4-6 tranches loans under a new multi-tranche finance facility (MFF). Depending 
on  the  speed  of  reforms,  and  development  of  ERA’s  capacity,  the  proposed  4  tranches  could  be 
converted to 5 to 6 tranches. The key assumptions underlying the scope of each loan are as follows: 
(i) sub-projects which are in an advanced stage of preparation, including the 4 core sub-projects will 
be covered by the first loan, along with master planning of the remaining components and capacity 
building;  (ii)  the  second  loan  will  commence  after  the  urban  sector  master  plans  for  water  supply, 
sewerage and traffic and transport have been updated and progress achieved on capacity building, 
improved  municipal  administration  and  introduction  of  cost  reflective  tariffs  and  reorganizing  the 
service  delivery  functions;  (iii)  the  third  loan  will  commence  after  detailed  master  plans  and 
environmental regulations are in place for the development of other important towns and commercial 
centers,  and  (iv)  the  fourth  loan  will  finance  works  requiring  longer  preparation  period.  The  total 

 investments in each phase, and the related loan amount of ADB’s loan program and the loan periods 
are summarized in Table 2 while the detailed implementation schedule is in Table 3. The envisaged

8. 
Policy  Dialogue  and  Capacity  Building  Program.  In  parallel  with  the  physical 
investments,  the  State  will  move  ahead  with  a  number  of  initiatives  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of 
Jammu and Srinagar municipal corporations. Traditionally under the State’s Development Act, 1970 
provision of water, sewerage and major drainage and urban roads in the cities and district towns was 
provided  through  the  PHED,  UEED  and  PWD,  respectively.  The  cities  were  responsible  for  solid 
waste  management  and  local  drainage.  In  year  2000,  the  State  established  the  Municipal 
Corporation Act which when fully implemented will shift much more responsibility for basic services 
to  the  corporations.  However,  the  corporations  have  only  been  operating  for  just  over  1  year,  with 
the first elections for council held in 2005.

SCHEDULE 3: IMPLEMENTATION FRAMEWORK 

 

 
Unless  modified  and  amended  in  loan  or  project  agreements  under  the  Facility,  the 

1. 
Investment Program will be implemented as follows: 
 
2. 
ERA  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  Investment  Program  and  responsible  for  overall 
strategic  guidance,  technical  supervision  and  work  quality  and  ensuring  compliance  with  loan  and 
PFR provisions and due diligence. The CEO of ERA will report to the Governing body chaired by the 
Minister  for  Planning  of  the  State.  Two  Project  Management  Units  (PMU)  under  ERA,  are  already 
established  in Srinagar and Jammu, with each PMU headed by a full-time Project Director, reporting 
to  the  CEO.  The  Project  Directors,  will  be  supported  by  PMU  staff  comprising  ,  water  supply, 
sewerage,  solid  waste  management,  urban  transportation,  financial  and    economic  analysts, 
procurement,  social  development,  environmental  and  procurement  specialists  and  project  advisory 
consultants.  A  senior  officer,  directly  reporting  to  the  CEO  and  supported  by  institutional,  financial 
and  municipal  management  specialists  and  consultants  will  also  be  appointed  to  oversee  the 
institutional development and capacity building program. Another senior officer, reporting directly to 
the  CEO  will  be  appointed  for  ensuring  compliance  with  environmental  and  social  safeguards 
policies.  Each  PMU  will  have  a  dedicated  Financial/Accounts  officer  to  look  after  the  project 
accounts and processing claims. 
 
The PMUs will be responsible for the identification, formulation and implementation of all sub-
3. 
projects  including  ensuring  conformance  with  state,  national  and  ADB  social  and  environmental 
safeguards policies. Staff on deputation from the line agencies/ municipalities or recruited from the 
market, under the direction of the Project Director of each PMU will be responsible for the day to day 
implementation  of  the  MFF  including  detailed  planning  and  design,  tendering,  construction 
supervision, quality control, processing and checking of contractors’ progress claims and reporting. 
A City Level Steering Committee will coordinate activities with the agencies at the city level and will 
also be responsible for dissemination of information to the public.  
 
4. 
Operation  and  Maintenance.  Current  practice  in  the  State,  is  for  the  PHED  and  UEED 
respectively, to operate and maintain the water and sewerage systems for all towns and Jammu and 
Srinagar cities. The new and improved water and sewerage facilities will be operated and managed 
by PHED and UEED, respectively in the short term.  
 
5. 
Governance  and  Anticorruption:  The  EA  will  ensure  compliance  with  the  specific 
anticorruption and governance risk mitigation measures, which are identified in Table below during 
Investment Program implementation.

SCHEDULE 4: SELECTION CRITERIA AND APPROVAL PROCESS FOR SUBPROJECTS 

 
1. 
Selection  of  Components.  The  facility  will  support  the  cities  of  Jammu  and  Srinagar,  and 
other  participating  towns  and  commercial  centers  in  developing  basic  urban  services:  (i)  water 
supply, (ii) sewerage and drainage, (iii) solid waste management (iv) urban transport and (v) other 
urban/  municipal  infrastructure.  These  services  together  with  Institutional  development  and 
Implementation assistance have been amalgamated into 6 components as follows: 

(i) 
(ii) 
(iii) 
(iv) 
(v) 
(vi) 

Component A: Water Supply; 
Component B: Sewerage and Drainage; 
Component C: Solid Waste management; 
Component D: Urban Transport; 
Component E: Other urban/municipal infrastructure; 
Component F: Capacity Building, Institutional development Governance and  

Investment Program Support  

 
2. 
Components  A,  B,  C,  D,  and  F  will  commence  early  in  the  Investment  Program  while 
Components E will be not be undertaken until completion of the Economic Opportunity Development 
Plan(EODP) /Master Plan of the sub-sector.

(d)

4. 
Urban Transport. Works related to improvement of riding quality, reduction of 
traffic  congestion,  widening  of  existing  roads,  Bypass  arrangements,  car  parking 
arrangements and improvement of pedestrian facilities. 

(a)  Work is limited to internal roads, and National Highways are excluded from the 

MFF. 

(b)  Works related to Mass transit system are also excluded from the MFF. 

Other Municipal/urban Infrastructure  

 
Support for  works relating to area  development/commercial infrastructure will 
be  only  to  those  identified  by  the  Economic  Opportunity  Development 
Plan(EODP)/ Master Plan.  

Proposals  for  construction  of  slaughter  houses  will  be  conditional  to  the 
establishment of waste treatment and disposal facilities. 

Other  works  relating  to  obligatory  municipal  functions  will  be  subject  to  a 
situation  report  and  within  a  road  map  for  improvements  in  the  service 
functions.

Resettlement  Framework.  This  Resettlement  Framework  has  been  prepared  to  set  out  the

The  Economic  Reconstruction  Agency  (ERA)  of  the  State  government  is  the  Executing

8. 
The  resettlement  policies  that  apply  will  include  India’s  National  Policy  on  Resettement  & 
Rehabilitation,  J&K  State  Laws  and  ADB’s  policy  requirements.  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary 

 

 36 

 

Resettlement  (1995)    will  guide  identification  of  impacts  and  plans    to  mitigate  various  losses  to 
affected people by the various subprojects. The key aspects of the Policy are summarized below: 
 
 

(i) 

Involuntary resettlement (IR) should be avoided or reduced as much as possible by reviewing 
alternatives to the Project; 

(ii)  Where IR is unavoidable, AP should be assisted to re-establish themselves and improve their 

quality of life; 

(iii) 

AP should be fully involved in the selection of relocation sites, livelihood compensation and 
development  options  at  the  earliest  opportunity.  RPs  should  also  be  prepared  in  full 
consultation with AP, including disclosure of RP and project related information; 

(iv)  Replacement  land  should  be  an  option  for  compensation  in  the  case  of  loss  of  land;  in  the 
absence  of  replacement  land,  cash-for-land  compensation  should  be  an  option  available 
each AP; 

(v)  Compensation for loss of land, structures, other assets and income should be based on full 
replacement cost and should be paid promptly. This should include transaction costs; 

(vi) 

All  compensation  payments  and  related  activities  should  be  completed  prior  to  the 
commencement of civil works; 

(vii)  RP should be planned and implemented with full participation of local authorities; 

(viii) 

In  the  event  of  necessary  relocation,  APs  should  be  assisted  to  integrate  into  host 
communities; 

(ix)  Common property resources and community/public services should be provided to AP; 

(x)  Resettlement should be planned as a development activity for the AP; 

(xi) 

AP who do not have documented title to land should receive fair and just treatment; and 

(xii) 

Vulnerable groups (households below the recognised poverty line; disabled, elderly persons 
or  female  headed  households)  should  be  identified  and  given  appropriate  assistance  to 
substantially improve their living standards.

they will encounter any adverse socio-cultural or economic impacts as a result of the MFF. The key

17. 
Environmental  Assessment  and  Review  Framework.  The  Environmental  Assessment  and 
Review  Framework  (EARF)  (Attachment  3)  of  JKUSDP  aims  at  (i)  determining  the  anticipated 
environmental  impacts  arising  from  subproject  implementation  based  on  an  examination  of  four   
subprojects  in  Jammu  and  Srinagar;  (ii)  identifying  environmental  mitigation  measures  and 
environmental monitoring plans required to address anticipated negative environmental impacts; (iii) 
providing  formats  and  guidelines  for  selecting  future  subprojects  based  on  environmental  eligibility 
criteria and conducting environmental examinations; and (iv) defining the Environmental Assessment 
and Review Framework for future subprojects proposed under JKUSDIP. 
 
18. 
Though the proposed JKUSDP aims to improve the environmental quality of the urban areas, 
the  development  of  infrastructure  facilities  may  potentially  cause  certain  negative  environmental 
impacts.  The  implementation  of  subprojects  can  have  adverse  impacts  on  various  environmental 
aspects  namely:  (i)  topography  and  drainage;  (ii)  soil  and  land  use;  (iii)  surface  water;  (iv) 
groundwater resources; (v) ambient air quality; (vi) noise levels; (vii) biotic environment; (viii) cultural 
and historic sites; and (ix) other socio-economic impacts.  These impacts may arise in the project life 
cycle  either  during  implementation  and/or  during  operation  phase  and  in  limited  cases,  may  also 
arise  after  end  of  operation  period.    The  potential  environmental  impacts  are  categorized  into  (i) 
location  impacts;  (ii)  design  impacts;  (iii)  construction  impacts;  and  (iv)  operation  and  maintenance 
impacts. 
 
19. 
The  SIEE  and  IEEs  conducted  for  the  subprojects  reveal  that  these  typical  urban 
infrastructure  projects,  owing  to  their  scale  and  magnitude  of  activities  coupled  with  the 
environmental  setting  of  the  Jammu  and  Kashmir,  are  unlikely  to  have  any  significant  adverse 
environmental impacts, except for the subprojects under MSW management component.  Based on 
the IEEs of the   subprojects, all the   subprojects identified in Jammu and Srinagar under JKUSDP, 
except  the  MSW  management  facility  at  Srinagar,  have  been  categorised  as  Category  ‘B’.    The 
MSW management facility at Srinagar is categorised as ‘B Sensitive.  The JKUSDP is classified as 
environmental category ‘B Sensitive’  in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy 2002.   
 
20. 
ERA is responsible as through the PMU for (i) preparing a rapid environmental assessment 
(REA), an initial environmental examination (IEE) and a summary IEE (SIEE) of eligible subprojects; 
(ii) implementing the environmental management plan (EMP) and environmental monitoring plan as 
stipulated in the IEE; and (iii) maintaining records of all documents related to environmental aspects 
of subprojects for disclosure by the PMUs, and (iv) supervising the PMUs for the implementation of 
environmental  management  and  monitoring  plans.  ERA  will  ensure  that  subprojects  are  properly 
selected. ADB will review and conform the environmental classification. if any of the follow-on sub-
projects is classified to be of environment category A, then the environment category of the Project 
is re-categorized to the environment category A, prior to approval of such follow-on sub-project. ERA 
will further ensure that (i) environmental assessments for subprojects are conducted in line with the 
requirements of ADB, and that of national, state and local statutory environmental regulations; and 
(ii) the environmental management and monitoring plans are appropriately implemented 
 

  

39

ERA is responsible for ensuring that all environmental assessment documentation, including 
21. 
monitoring the implementation of EMPs, and environmental monitoring plans shall be systematically 
documented.  The environmental assessment documents are subject to public disclosure and shall 
be made available, if required. ERA shall ensure that in carrying out an IEE for any subproject under 
JKUSDP,  at  least  one  step  consultation  with  the  affected  people,  will  be  done  to  gather  their 
concerns about the subproject, particularly in respect of its potential impacts. If an EIA is required, 
ERA  shall  ensure  that  two  step  consultations  with  affected  people  are  undertaken.  The  first 
consultation  aims  to  gather  their  concerns  about  the  subprojects,  particularly  in  respect  of  its 
potential impacts.  The second consultation aims to share the EMP with affected people and gather 
their views on the EMP.  
 
22. 
The safeguard requirements for each financing tranche, as well as the categorization of each 
loan for environmental impact purposes, will follow the approach and procedure defined in existing 
ADB Safeguard Polices. For any subproject other than the four appraised subprojects under the first 
loan, categorized as A or B Sensitive, the respective SEIA  or SIEE must be circulated to the ADB 
Board and made available to the general public 120 days before approval of this subproject. If any of 
the investments or subprojects in any subsequent loan requires compliance with the same 120-day 
advance disclosure rule, the SEIA or SIEE must be circulated to the ADB Board and made available 
to the general public 120 days before a PFR is submitted to ADB. Environmental assessment reports 
for ADB projects will be accessible to interested parties and the general public. The SIEE and SEIA 
reports  are  required  to  be  circulated  worldwide,  through  the  depository  library  system  and  on  the 
ADB website. The full EIA or IEE reports are also made available to interested parties on request. 
 
23. 
An Environmental Monitoring Plan will be prepared for each subproject.  The monitoring plan 
presents  the  recommended  environmental  monitoring  activities  which  indicate  the  effectiveness  of 
the  EMP  in  mitigating  negative  impacts  identified  in  the  IEE.    The  plan  will  also  identify  the 
agencies/institutions  that  are  responsible  for  monitoring.  ERA  will  submit  to  ADB  semiannual 
progress reports on the implementation of the EMPs and the environmental monitoring carried out as 
a regular part of project implementation.  The environmental monitoring report will be made available 
to  the  public  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Public  Communications  Policy  (2005).    The  ERA  has  the 
overall  responsibility  to  monitor  the  implementation  of  EMP,  including  the  environmental  mitigation 
measures for all subprojects under JKUSDP.   
 
24. 
ERA will with the help of the consultants, review the IEEs/EIAs and corresponding EMPs to 
ensure  that  the  mitigation  measures  and  monitoring  plan  proposed  are  adequate  and  conform  to 
ADB’s environmental and social safeguard policies. ERA will provide ADB with access to information 
on any subproject, as needed.  The information on the implementation of the EMP, as well as that on 
the environmental safeguard compliance will be systematically documented and reported to ADB as 
a  part  of  the  quarterly  reports  containing  a  section  on  the  implementation  of  the  EMP  and 
environmental monitoring plan.

Jammu  and  Kashmir  Urban  Sector  Development  Investment  Program  (JKUSDIP)  is  under 
preparation  as  a  sector  loan  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  for  improving  infrastructure  and 
municipal services in two municipal corporations of Jammu and Srinagar cities and selected tourist 
centres1  and  other  important  towns,  within  Jammu  and  Kashmir  State.  The  Project  will  include

2. 
In order to prepare and process the Project in accordance with ADB’s procedures for sector 
lending, a set of four subprojects have been selected one each in each of the four major urban sub-
sectors  namely  –  Water  Supply,  Sewerage,  Solid  Waste  Management  and  Urban  Transport  in  the 
two cities of Jammu and Srinagar. In keeping with ADB’s sector loan procedures; this resettlement 
framework  has  been  prepared  to  set  out  the  resettlement  policy  and  screening  and  planning 
procedures  that  will  apply  to  subprojects,  components,  or  investments  that  are  prepared  and 
approved during loan implementation to ensure that they conform to ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement 
Policy.  The  Framework  thus,  identifies  the  broad  scope  of  the  project  and  outlines  the  policy, 
procedures  for  acquisition  of  land,  compensation  and  other  assistance  measures  for  affected 
persons and institutional requirements for preparing subsequent sub-projects under the sector loan.

3. 
The resettlement principles adopted in this framework recognize the State Land Acquisition 
(LA) Act 1990 and the entitlement benefits as listed in the National Policy on R&R, (Govt of India) as 
notified in February 2004 and the relevant Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) policies and operations 
manuals, in particular the Policy on Involuntary Resettlement (1995), and Operations Manual F2 on 
Involuntary Resettlement (2003).

the  basic  principles  for  the  Project  will  include  the  following  elements  with  respect  to  each 
subproject:  
 

Resettlement Policy and Framework

minimized as much as possible;

order to improve or at least restore the pre-Project income and living standards of the affected 
people; 

c)  Consultation  with  affected  people  on  compensation  options  and  preparation  Resettlement 

Plan (RP) in accordance with this Framework; 

d)  Payment of compensation for acquired assets at market/replacement rates;

b)  If  impacts  are  found  to  be  “significant,”3  a  full  RP  will  be  prepared    for  each  subproject  for 

approval prior to award of contracts for that subproject;   

c)  If subproject impacts are less than significant, a short RP will be prepared for that subproject 

for approval prior to award of contracts for that subproject; and  

d)  The  RP  would  also  include  measures  to  ensure  that  socio-economic  condition,  needs  and 
priorities  of women  are  identified  and  that  the  process  of  land  acquisition  and  resettlement 
does not disadvantage women.   

 
6. 
The  RP  prepared  for  the  subproject  will  be  used  as  a  model  for  the  preparation  of 
subsequent  RPs.  The  RPs  shall  comply  with  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  and  other 
social safeguard guidelines. The additional full or short RPs will be disclosed to the APs, endorsed 
by  the  EA  and  will  be  submitted  to  ADB  for  approval  prior  to  award  of  civil  works  contracts  for  a 
subproject. The full RP, not just the summary will be disclosed to the APs as well as uploaded on the 
ADB website after ADB review and approval. In case impacts on Indigenous People are identified,

Attachment 2 

INDIGENOUS PEOPLE’S DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK 

A. 

Project Introduction 

1. 
Jammu and Kashmir Urban Development Sector Project (JKUDSP) is under preparation for 
sector  loan  funding  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  for  improving  infrastructure  and  municipal 
services in two municipal corporations and selected tourist centres within Jammu and Kashmir State.  
The  two  cities  are  Jammu  and  Srinagar.    The  tourist  centres  and  other  important  towns  initially 
selected for consideration are Patnitop (Jammu region), Gulmarg, Pahalgam and Sonmarg (Kashmir 
region).    The  project  will  include  investment  in  physical  infrastructure  plus  proposals  for  capacity 
building and institutional strengthening of city and state authorities. 

2. 
In accordance with ADB’s procedure for sector lending, a set of four sample subprojects have 
been selected in the two Project cities of Srinagar & Jammu for project preparation and processing 
in  each  of  the  four  major  urban  sub-sectors  namely  –  Water  Supply,  Sewerage,  Solid  Waste 
Management, and Urban Transport.  Out of these four sample subprojects, two sample subprojects 
have been selected in Jammu city and two sample subprojects in Srinagar City. 

3. 
Since the Project is mainly concentrated in the cities of Jammu and Srinagar, a very limited 
presence  of  IP  households  was  noted  in  the  socio-economic  survey  (SES)  undertaken  during  the 
course  of  initial  poverty  and  social  analysis.  No  adverse  impacts  of  the  subprojects  have  been 
identified on the IP households in any of the sample subprojects.  It would also be worthwhile to note 
that the IP households were positive about the subproject and did not feel that they will encounter 
any  adverse  socio-cultural  or  economic  impacts  as  a  result  of  the  Project.  The  key  benefits 
envisaged out of the Project mainly comprise of a sustained improvements in basic service provision 
within the cities of Jammu and Srinagar and other important towns.  Indirect benefits will be available 
in the form of improved living conditions, a healthier living environment and the prospect of improved 
health status of the population plus an improved economic climate with employment opportunities.  

Nonetheless, this Indigenous Peoples Development Framework (IPDF) is intended to guide 
4. 
selection and preparation of additional subprojects under the Project where impacts on tribal people 
are  identified  to  ensure  better  distribution  of  the  Project  benefits  and  promote  development  of  the 
indigenous  peoples  in  the  Project  areas.    The  framework  is  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
procedures for sector loans as presented in ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 
 
B. 

Indigenous/Tribal Groups 

The terms ‘indigenous peoples’, indigenous ethnic minorities’, tribal groups,’ and ‘scheduled 
5. 
tribes’ describe social groups with a social and cultural identity distinct from the dominant society that 
makes them vulnerable to being disadvantaged in the development process.  By definition, IP refers 
to peoples living in an area within a nation-state, prior to the formation of a nation-state, but who do 
not  identify  with  the  dominant  nation.    This  group  has  social,  cultural,  economic,  and  political 
traditions and institutions distinct from the mainstream or dominant society and culture.   

6. 
ADB  uses  the  following  characteristics  to  define  indigenous  people:  (i)  descent  from 
population groups present in a given area before territories were defined; (ii) maintenance of cultural 
and  social  identities  separate  from  dominant  societies  and  cultures;  (iii)  self  identification  and 
identification by others as being part of a distinct cultural group; (iv) linguistic identity different from 

 

 50 

 

that of dominant society; (v) social, cultural, economic and political traditions and institutions distinct 
from dominant culture; (vi) economic systems oriented more towards traditional production systems 
rather  than  mainstream;  and  (vii)  unique  ties  and  attachments  to  traditional  habitats  and  ancestral 
territories.  Essentially,  indigenous  people  have  a  social  and  cultural  identity  distinct  from  the 
mainstream society that makes them vulnerable to being overlooked in development processes. 
 
C. 

Indigenous Peoples Development Framework Objectives 

The  Indigenous  Peoples  Development  Framework  seeks  to  ensure  that  indigenous  people 
9. 
and  tribal  communities  are  informed,  consulted  and  mobilized  to  participate  in  the  subproject 
preparation. The Framework is intended to guide selection and preparation of additional subprojects 
under  the  Project  where  impacts  on  tribal  people  are  identified  to  ensure  better  distribution  of  the 
Project  benefits  and  promote  development  of  the  indigenous  peoples  in  the  Project  areas.    The 
framework is prepared in accordance with ADB’s procedures for sector loans as presented in ADB’s 
Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). 

 
D. 

IPDP Policy Framework 

10. 
ADB's Policy on Indigenous People (IPs) aims to protect ethnic minorities from the adverse 
impact of development, and to ensure that ethnic minorities benefit from development projects and 
programs.  The need for a full IPDP will depend on the nature and magnitude of the Project impacts 
and sensitivity of IP issues.  The need for the IPDP will be established on the basis of the following 
criteria set out in ADB’s Policy on IP, to determine if project impacts are ‘significant’:  

(i) adverse impacts on customary rights of use and access to land & natural resources;  

(ii) negative impacts on socio-economic status and cultural identity;  

(iii) impacts on health, education, livelihood and social security status; and 

(iv)  any  other  impacts  that  may  alter  or  undermine  indigenous  knowledge  and  customary 
institutions.  

11. 
The  IPDP  will  ensure  that  project  affected  IPs  are,  as  well  off  with  the  project  as  without  it 
after the implementation of the plan. This plan will also aim to identify measures towards satisfying 
the needs and developmental aspirations of IPs. 

If,  the  impacts  on  IP’s  are  insignificant11,  then  specific  actions  in  favour  of  the  indigenous 
12. 
people will need to be integrated in the Resettlement Plan for the subprojects or a community / tribal 
development plan. This would ensure appropriate mitigations and benefits for the indigenous people.  

Based on both India’s legal, constitutional and developmental strategies and ADB’s policy on 

13. 
indigenous people, the objectives of an IPDP will be as follows: 

(i)  Ensure that tribal/ST people affected by any subproject will benefit from the subproject;  

                                                 
11  Impacts  are  insignificant  when  the  fewer  than  100  Indigenous  People  are  affected,  a  full  Indigenous  Peoples 
Development Plan (IPDP) is not required but impacts and mitigation measures can be dealt through the RP. Impacts are 
considered  to  be  ‘significant’  when  more  than  100  Indigenous  People  are  affected  by  the  Project  thereby  requiring  a 
separate IPDP.   

  

51

(ii) Ensure tribal inclusion in the entire process of planning, implementation and monitoring of 
the subproject;  

(iii) Ensure that the benefits of the subprojects are available to STs/SCs more than or at least 
at  par  with  other  affected  groups;  this  may  require  giving  preference  to  tribal  people  as 
vulnerable groups over others on certain benefits under the subprojects; and 

(iv) Provide a base for the tribal groups in the area to receive adequate development focus 
and attention. 

 
E. 

Procedure for Preparing an IPDP 

14. 

In order to prepare an IPDP the following steps will be undertaken: 

(i)  Based  on  the  social  assessment,  establish  baseline  data  on  the  tribal  people  
(subsistence,  employment,  community  networks)  affected  by  the  project  (use  the  criteria  in 
the section above to determine project impacts); 

(ii) Review policy guidelines both at national and state level regarding STs; 

(iii)  If  the  impacts  are  considered  significant  as  defined  above,  prepare  an  IPDP  based  on 
ADB’s Policy on Indigenous People; 

(iv) Submit IPDP to ADB for review and approval. 

 
15. 
As  enumerated  above,  the  main  features  of  the  IPDP  will  thus  comprise  of  a  preliminary 
screening process, followed by a social impact assessment to determine the degree and nature of 
impact of each subproject, and an action plan will be developed if warranted.  Each of these steps 
have been further elucidated in the sections below: 

1.  

Screening 

16. 
The  Project  Management  Unit  (PMU)  and  Design  &  Supervision  Consultants  (DSC) 
responsible  for  subproject  preparation  and  implementation  will  visit  all  tribal  settlements  near  the 
subproject  areas  or  in  likelihood  of  being  affected  and  influenced  by  the  subproject  components.  
Public  meetings  will  be  arranged  in  selected  tribal  communities  by  the  PMU  and  DSC  to  provide 
them information about the subproject and take their views on the subproject. 

17. 
During this visit, the social specialist of the DSC and PMU will undertake a screening of the 
tribal  communities  with the  help  of  the  community  leaders  and  local  authorities.  The  screening  will 
cover the following aspects: 

(i)  Name(s) of tribal community group(s) in the area; 

(ii) Total number of tribal community groups in the area; 

(iii) Percentage of tribal community population to that of total area/locality population; 

(iv) Number and percentage of tribal community households along the zone of influence of 
the proposed subproject. 

 

 52 

 

If the results of the screening bring forth the presence of tribal community households in the 
18. 
zone of influence of the proposed subproject, a social impact assessment will be planned for those 
areas. 
 

2. 

Social Impact Assessment 

19. 
The  DSC  and  PMU  will  undertake  a  social  impact  assessment  (SIA).    The  SIA  will  gather 
relevant  information  on  demographic  data;  social,  cultural  and  economic  situation;  and  social, 
cultural  and  economic  impacts  –  positive  and  negative  on  the  tribal  communities  in  the  subproject 
area. 

20. 
Information  will  be  gathered  from  separate  group  meetings  within  the  tribal  community, 
including  tribal  leaders;  group  of  tribal  men  and  women,  especially  those  who  live  in  the  zone  of 
influence of the proposed subproject under the Project.  Discussions will focus on the positive and 
negative  impacts  of  the  subproject  as  well  as  recommendations  on  the  design  of  the  subproject.  
The  PMU  and  the  DSC  will  be  responsible  for  analyzing  the  SIA  and  based  on  it  developing  an 
action  plan  with  the  tribal  community  leaders.    If  the  SIA  indicates  that  the  potential  impact  of  the 
proposed  Project  will  be  significantly  adverse  threatening  the  cultural  practices  and their  source  of 
livelihood, the PMU and DSC will consider other design options to minimize such adverse impacts 
and will prepare an Indigenous Peoples Development Plan (IPDP). 
 

3.  

Indigenous People Development Plan 

21. 
IPDP will consist of a number of activities and will include mitigation measures of potentially 
negative  impacts  by  means  of  modification  of  subproject  design  and  development  assistance.  
Where there is land acquisition in tribal communities, the Project will ensure that their rights will not 
be violated and that they will be compensated for the use of any part of their land in a manner that is 
culturally  acceptable  to  them.  The  compensation  will  be  in  keeping  with  Entitlement  Matrix  as 
provided in the Resettlement Framework of the Project.  The IPDP will include: 

(i) Baseline data; 
(ii) Land tenure information; 
(iii) Local participation; 
(iv)Technical identification of development or mitigation activities; 
(v) Institutional arrangement; 
(vi) Implementation schedule; 
(vii) Monitoring and evaluation; and 
(viii) Cost estimate and financing plan. 

Consultation & Disclosure  

22. 
The PMU will submit the IPDP through the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) to ADB for review 
and  approval  prior  to  the  selection  of  specific  subprojects.    The  IPDP  policy  and  measures  must 
comply with ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples. 
 
F. 
 
23. 
The  tribal  groups/IP  will  be  consulted  during  the  preparation  of  the  IPDP.    They  will  be 
informed of the mitigation measures proposed and their views will be taken into account in finalizing 
the  plan.    The  Plan  will  be  translated  into  the  tribal  language  and  made  available  to  the  affected 
people before implementation. The disclosure will be in a manner accessible to APs where there are 
differing levels of literacy skills.  

  

53

The  tribal  institutions  and  organizations  in  the  affected  area  will  also  be  involved  in 

24. 
implementing the IPDP and in resolving any disputes that may arise.  
 
G. 

Institutional Framework and Budget 

25. 
ERA  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  the  Project  which  will  have  two  Project 
Management  Units  (PMU)  headed  by  a  Regional  Director  each  in  the  city  of  Jammu  &  Srinagar, 
reporting to the CEO. The PMU will have the primary responsibility for the preparation of the IPDP 
supported by DSC.  The responsibility of financing, implementation and monitoring of the IPDP will 
rest  with  the  EA.    A  local  NGO/institution  with  the  relevant  experience  will  be  hired  to  assist  the 
PMUs  in  planning  and  implementing  the  IPDP.    The    independent  agency/institution  (that  may 
include  established  and  registered  NGO(s))will  be  fully  oriented  on  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous 
People. 

 
H. 

Monitoring and Evaluation 

26. 
The  PMU  will  set  up  an  internal  monitoring  system  comprising  Social  Development  & 
Resettlement Specialist, independent agency/institution (that may include established and registered 
NGO(s)),  tribal  people/IP  and  their  institutions  to  monitor  the  plan  implementation.    Monitoring 
indicators  will  be  established.  In  addition,  an  external  independent  monitoring  agency  will  be 
engaged by the EA with ADB concurrence to undertake independent external monitoring of the Plan.  
Reporting / monitoring formats will be prepared for both internal and external monitoring. 
 
27. 
final approval. 
 
 

Any IPDPs prepared under this Project will be endorsed by the EA before sending to ADB for
